premise: It is impossible for a single person to down a pound of meat in the course of one meal.
hypothesis: Some people can down a pound of meat in the course of one meal.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The metaphor states that the person is downing  (i.e., typically connotes eating or consuming something quickly) a full pound of meat during a single meal, which contradicts in the another statement that it is impossible to do.

premise: But the next morning, it sounds terrible
hypothesis: But the next morning, it sounds like a sick cat.
label: Entailment
explanation: A sick cat usually sounds terrible, as opposed to a healthy cat.

premise: He pushed himself through the rift without so much as a goodbye, or even a pleased feeling that he would never have to see that person again.
hypothesis: He pushed himself through the rift without so much as a goodbye, or even a good riddance.
label: Entailment
explanation: To wish someone good riddance is to be pleased that they are leaving, and in this context he is pleased that he will never have to see that person again.

premise: I ordered a medium latte, no sugar from starbucks and they completely got my order wrong
hypothesis: I love how Starbucks could mess up my simple order of a medium latte with no sugar
label: Contradiction
explanation: Starbucks is a well-known coffee chain and so someone ordering from them would expect their order to be correct and would not love it if the order is messed up.

premise: There was a hair baked into one of my raviolis , super long and not mine at all.
hypothesis: Was disgusted to find an odd hair baked into one of my raviolis and it definitely was not mine
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often considered gross to find hair in food, especially if it is not your own, and so people are generally disgusted when they find a hair in their food.

premise: And then ignore and flex and yell after!.
hypothesis: And then suck it up and flex and yell after!
label: Contradiction
explanation: To suck it up means to endure something painful or unpleasant, but in this context the person is ignoring the pain of flexing.

premise: The greatest lesson I learned is that by doing what you love supremely well, you can influence the course of history in a positive way.
hypothesis: The greatest lesson I learned is that by doing what you love supremely well, you can make history.
label: Entailment
explanation: To make history means to do something memorable or spectacular enough to influence the course of history, and in this context the speaker is saying that by doing what you love well, you can make history

premise: It was completely outdated and unpopular when I went to use it last night.
hypothesis: It was dead as a dodo when I went to use it last night.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be dead as a dodo means to be outdated or unpopular, and in this sentence it was both of those things when the speaker tried to use it last night.

premise: I'm just saying that maybe you're a target because you messed up or ruined something.
hypothesis: I'm just saying that maybe you're a target because you upset the apple cart.
label: Entailment
explanation: To upset the apple cart means to mess up or ruin something, and in this context the person is saying that the reason why the person is a target is because they messed up.

premise: Towering over me, he looked at me with his lustful and seductive eyes.
hypothesis: Towering over me, he looked at me with his sexy bedroom eyes.
label: Entailment
explanation: To have bedroom eyes is to have a sultry suggestive gaze, which is what he was doing when he looked at the speaker with his lustful and seductive eyes.

premise: I was put in jail and felt really ashamed when my parents found out.
hypothesis: I was really embarrassed and ashamed when my parents found out I was put in jail
label: Entailment
explanation: Being put in jail is generally seen as a really bad thing and people are often embarrassed and ashamed when their family finds out because it reflects badly on them.

premise: People offering her the opportunity of a lifetime to become involved in something at its end of a great business opportunity.
hypothesis: People offering her the opportunity of a lifetime to get in on the ground floor of a great business opportunity.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get in on the ground floor means to become involved in something at its beginning, but in this sentence she would be getting involved at the end.

premise: Their reactions weren't typical, and to the best of my knowledge, they didn't go back inside the building and keep quiet about the situation.
hypothesis: Their reactions werent typical, and to the best of my knowledge, they didn't go back inside the building and cry foul.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cry foul is to protest against something, but in this sentence they are staying quiet about the situation.

premise: She was absolutely adorable
hypothesis: She was like a little seraph with bright brown eyes and a perfect button of a nose.
label: Entailment
explanation: A seraph is a celestial being, so she must be pretty perfect and adorable if she resembles one.

premise: She is so easily accessible
hypothesis: She is like a rare stone in a museum surrounded by laser lights.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A rare stone in a museum is carefully guarded and not easily accessible.

premise: I was ready to fly to Japan this morning, and when I arrived the airline had given away my seat to someone else!
hypothesis: I was so excited to fly to Japan this morning, but when I arrived at the airport I was furious to find out my seat had been given away to someone else!
label: Entailment
explanation: It is very common to be excited to fly to Japan because it is a beautiful country with a lot of history.

premise: I ruined my friends wedding because of my drunken behavior
hypothesis: I feel like such a responsible person because my drunken behavior at my friends wedding completely ruined the day.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A responsible person would not engage in drunken behavior that would ruin their friend's wedding day.

premise: I feel so envious when I drive through the rich neighborhoods and I know that I will never be able to live there.
hypothesis: I feel terrible when I drive through the rich neighborhoods and know that I will never be able to afford to live there
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel envious of people who have more money than you and can afford to live in nicer places.

premise: I just got notice that my mortgage payment has gone up this year and I'm so mad about it.
hypothesis: I am absolutely livid that my mortgage payment has increased this year without any warning
label: Entailment
explanation: Mortgage payments are often already very expensive and so when they go up it can be a huge financial burden on someone.

premise: I felt sad that I was not asked to be the bridesmaid at a close friends wedding
hypothesis: It made me feel pleased when I found out that I was not asked to be a bridesmaid in my close friend's wedding
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being a bridesmaid is often an honor and so not being asked to be one implies that the person is not valued as much as they thought they were and hence should not be pleased.

premise: Her hair smelled like a delicate fragrance that was lingering around me.
hypothesis: Of that faint fragrance rising from her soft hair.
label: Entailment
explanation: Delicate fragrance means a light scent that is not overwhelming.

premise: I recently noticed how much weight I gained over the past year and I just feel like I really let myself down.
hypothesis: I am thrilled about the amount of weight I gained over the past year and feel like really on top of the world
label: Contradiction
explanation: The act of gaining weight is often frowned upon and considered to be unhealthy, so someone who is happy about it cannot be thrilled but instead should feel ashamed.

premise: I'm stuck between the desire to run away quickly to memorial church, the nearest hallowed ground I can think of-or to not endure and not hear what he's going to say this time.
hypothesis: I'm torn between the desire to run-hightail it straight to memorial church, the nearest hallowed ground I can think of-or to suck it up and hear what he's going to say this time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To suck it up means to endure something painful or unpleasant, but the speaker in this context is considering not enduring it in order to avoid hearing what the other person has to say.

premise: he summoned the servant.
hypothesis: He buzzed the servant.
label: Entailment
explanation: He buzzed the servant means he asked for the servant.

premise: A neighbor mowed over my flower bed and now of my flowers were destroyed.
hypothesis: Cheerful about how a neighbor destroyed my flower bed and killed all my flowers when they were mowing their lawn
label: Contradiction
explanation: Neighbors are often responsible for taking care of each other's yards and gardens while mowing their lawns, so when one neighbor destroys another's flower bed and kills all the flowers, it is considered to be an act of negligence and nothing to cheer about.

premise: If I ate like this, I would become obese.
hypothesis: With rations like this, I would become like a knife .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A knife is a thin, sharp object, so saying someone would become like a knife implies they would become thin.

premise: I took a flight last week and there was awful turbulence.
hypothesis: I was just delighted when the airplane started to shake because of the wonderful turbulence
label: Contradiction
explanation: Turbulence on an airplane is often very scary and can cause panic, so someone who describes it as wonderful is not being truthful.

premise: After being hurt before, Brian now starts every relationship by not revealing anything about his intentions and keeping them hidden.
hypothesis: Once bitten twice shy, now Brian starts every relationship by putting his cards on the table.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To put your cards on the table means to reveal something hidden, such as intentions, but in this context Brian is keeping his intentions hidden.

premise: Earlier this week I was in the middle of an email and my computer shut down randomly.
hypothesis: I was so thrilled when my computer randomly shut down in the middle of an email this week.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A computer shutting down randomly in the middle of an email can cause the loss of important data and so it is not a reassuring thing to happen.

premise: Everyone used to love you.
hypothesis: You were the golden boy back then.
label: Entailment
explanation: To slowly dissolve blankness means the that the blankness will be gone.

premise: I broke my mother's prized teapot.
hypothesis: I feel great that I accidentally broke my mother's prized teapot
label: Contradiction
explanation: Accidentally breaking something that is valuable to someone shows carelessness and stupidity and hence the person who broke it should not feel great about it.

premise: Even though I knew the act was real, it was still a poor performance that got my heart racing.
hypothesis: It was a good performance that got my heart racing, even though I knew the act was like a street bought rolex.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Street bought rolexes are fake, so the act must be fake as well, and not real.

premise: I've been neglecting my friends lately I'm always working and never have time to hang out.
hypothesis: I feel delighted that I have not been able to make more time for my friends lately because I am always busy working
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not good to be too busy with work and neglect friends because friends are an important part of one's life.

premise: I don't like it when mosquitoes attack me while I'm having a good time at the beach
hypothesis: I don't appreciate it when mosquitoes ruin my good time by attacking me while I'm at the beach
label: Entailment
explanation: Mosquitoes often spread diseases and their bites can be very itchy and annoying so when they attack people while they're trying to enjoy themselves it's understandable to not appreciate it.

premise: I got recently got three rejection letters for 3 different jobs in a matter of a week and a half and that was a painful experience.
hypothesis: I was jumping for joy when I received 3 rejection letters for different jobs in such a short amount of time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Rejection letters for job applications are never a good thing to receive and rather painful and so someone being happy about getting them is unreal.

premise: The touch of his calloused fingers against my elbow was powerful
hypothesis: The touch of his calloused fingers against my elbow was like an alien tractor beam.
label: Entailment
explanation: A tractor beam is a powerful beam of energy used to move objects, so the simile is indicating that the man's touch was similarly powerful.

premise: It was either him or me who would fail.
hypothesis: It was either him or me who would bite the dust.
label: Entailment
explanation: To bite the dust means to fail, and in this sentence it is either him or the speaker who will fail.

premise: I knew pain existed, and this was mild.
hypothesis: I knew there was pain but this was like a sharp dagger.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sharp dagger is a very painful experience, whereas something that is mild would not be considered as painful as a sharp dagger.

premise: I'm on a diet and I ate three chocolate bars yesterday.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I cheated on my diet by eating three chocolate bars yesterday
label: Entailment
explanation: Diets are often based on denial of certain cravings and indulgences and so eating something that is restricted is usually seen as a cheat which can lead to feelings of guilt and shame.

premise: We have come to the realization that the end of the world is preventable.
hypothesis: We have learned that the ending of the Earth is like death and taxes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Death and taxes are both inevitable, so saying the end of the ending of the Earth is like death and taxes means it is also inevitable.

premise: He was frustrated and surprised, that he'd been locked in the trunk by this muscle-headed jackie chan.
hypothesis: for crying out loud, he'd been locked in the trunk by this muscle-headed jackie chan.
label: Entailment
explanation: For crying out loud is an expression of frustration or surprise, which is how he felt after being locked in the trunk.

premise: The things that come in between the two are unpleasant
hypothesis: The things that wait in between the two are like Scylla and Charybdas.
label: Entailment
explanation: Scylla and Charybdas are two sea monsters in Greek mythology who were known for devouring sailors.

premise: There was the obstacle for him to do something very risky and dangerous and satisfy his curiosity.
hypothesis: There was the obstacle for him to take the plunge and satisfy his curiosity.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take the plunge means to commit oneself to a course of action that is very risky or challenging, which is what he would have to do to satisfy his curiosity.

premise: I racked up a lot of money on my credit card shortly after paying it off.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I charged a lot of money on my credit card shortly after paying it off in full
label: Entailment
explanation: It often feels bad to spend a lot of money on a credit card after working hard to pay it off, because it means that someone will have to start paying interest on the balance again.

premise: I can't stand a messy kitchen but my roommate is a pig.
hypothesis: I feel satisfied every time I see the kitchen because my roommate never cleans up after himself
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing the kitchen in a state of disarray would not be a satisfying sight for anyone, considering that it is the place where food is prepared and hence should be kept clean.

premise: I began taking strides so small it was barely walking.
hypothesis: Without realizing it I began taking strides like a superannuated ballet-dancer .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A superannuated ballet dancer is someone who is a veteran and expert, so they would be taking long, graceful strides like a professional dancer, not small steps.

premise: Sunset takes place in the evening.
hypothesis: From its blue vase the rose of evening drops.
label: Entailment
explanation: The rose of evening is a metaphor for the setting sun.

premise: I order food almost every day now and will never get healthy
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I am not eating healthy because I am ordering food almost every day now
label: Entailment
explanation: It is common knowledge that ordering food is not as healthy as cooking a meal from scratch and so if someone is doing it every day they are likely to feel bad about their lack of healthy eating.

premise: In the depth of the night I wake up from the bed.
hypothesis: In the depth of the night I sprawl in the bed.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To sprawl in the bed means to lay down in a relaxed or lazy manner, while to wake up from the bed means to get up and leave it.

premise: The employee expresses her anger.
hypothesis: The employee swallows her anger.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To swallow something means to suppress it or keep it hidden, while to express something means to communicate it openly.

premise: I was irritated when I was at the airport and someone cut in line.
hypothesis: I was so mad when I saw someone jump the queue and cut in line at the airport
label: Entailment
explanation: It is considered very rude to cut in line and so when someone does it, it often irritates the people who were waiting patiently.

premise: I went to the store today and realized I took an item without paying
hypothesis: I feel very ashamed that I walked out of the store today without paying for the item I picked up
label: Entailment
explanation: It is wrong to take something from a store without paying and so feeling ashamed and embarrassed is a natural reaction to such an event.

premise: I told my kids to clean while I was gone and the house looked worse than before I left
hypothesis: I got home and found out my angelic kids only made the house dirtier when I told them to clean it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Kids are often disobedient and do not listen to what their parents tell them so making the housing messier when asked to clean is not being angelic.

premise: I came home from a business trip and found food rotting in the fridge with mold growing on everything and fruit flies swarming around.
hypothesis: I came home from a business trip and found the fridge full of rotten food, moldy produce, and fruit flies everywhere
label: Entailment
explanation: Coming home to food that has gone bad, is moldy, and has fruit flies buzzing around is pretty gross and unpleasant.

premise: Despite his rival's efforts, the politician won.
hypothesis: The politician toppled his rival.
label: Entailment
explanation: Toppled means to defeat someone or something.

premise: Sarah was too fragile and delicate to handle it like some other women could.
hypothesis: Some women could handle it, but sarah was like a translucent piece of china.
label: Entailment
explanation: A piece of china is very fragile and can easily break, so Sarah is too fragile to handle it.

premise: My coworker was able to find a new job within like a week, meanwhile I am at the same horrible company.
hypothesis: It's really motivating how my coworker was able to find a new job within a week while I am still stuck at this horrible company
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not motivating at all because it shows how the speaker's coworker was able to find a new job quickly while the speaker is still stuck in a place they hate, which implies the speaker's dissatisfaction.

premise: The smoke rising from the pyrotechnics was so thin it was easy to see.
hypothesis: Smoke rising from erupting pyrotechnics was like a london fog.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A london fog is very thick, so it would be hard to see through, whereas if the smoke from the pyrotechnics is thin, it would be easy to see.

premise: Even though Santiago wasn't convinced, he turned his attention to the vampire who was pacing back and forth in the cellar, and her movements were clumsy.
hypothesis: Santiago wasn't entirely convinced, but he turned his attention to the beautiful vampire, who was busy pacing from one end of the cellar to the other, her movements like a water sprite.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A water sprite is a light and delicate creature, so her movements would be graceful and not clumsy.

premise: Through enough proof and established facts, coincidences didn't really exist
hypothesis: in my book coincidences didn't really exist.
label: Contradiction
explanation: In my book means according to someone's opinion, judgment or values, but this context is saying that coincidences don't exist through proof and established facts and not based on indiviual opinion.

premise: I get out of bed and move backward away from the shower.
hypothesis: I get out of bed and go straight into the shower.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go straight means to move forward in the direction one is facing, but in this sentence the person moves backward.

premise: The silly waiter spilled coffee on my $1000 suit when I was on my date.
hypothesis: That amazing waiter ruined my date and also spilled coffee on my $1000 suit
label: Contradiction
explanation: A waiter ruining someone's date and spilling coffee on an expensive suit would not be considered amazing and instead would be seen as a blunder and a silly move.

premise: They were very eager when we made contact with them.
hypothesis: But when we made contact with them they were like shy kindergarteners.
label: Contradiction
explanation: When people are shy, they are typically not eager, and kindergarteners are often shy around adults.

premise: I may not want to settle down with my women, but I always share secrets about them that could cause problems.
hypothesis: I may not want to settle down with my women, but I never tell tales on them.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To tell tales means to share secrets, often knowing that doing so will cause problems for someone else but in this context, the speaker is saying they would always do something that could cause problems for their women that contradicts not telling tales on them.

premise: All sorts of theories and speculations floated about the internet and the yak: mental strength accepting defeat in front of physical threats or difficulties, generators telepathic communication devices.
hypothesis: All sorts of theories and speculations floated about the internet and the yak: mind over matter generators, telepathic communication devices...
label: Contradiction
explanation: Mind over matter refers to intellectual powers overriding threats or difficulties, but in this context it refers to mental strength accepting defeat.

premise: The conversation avoided politics.
hypothesis: The conversation gravitated towards politics.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To gravitate towards something means to be attracted to it or drawn in by it, while to avoid something means to stay away from it or steer clear of it.

premise: I cannot find my mailbox key anywhere
hypothesis: I'm totally not frustrated at how I can't find my mailbox key anywhere
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would find it really frustrating to not be able to find their mailbox key because it is a necessary item for retrieving mail, so someone who is having a great time despite this situation is not being truthful.

premise: This story, however, is about a god who is powerful.
hypothesis: This tale, however, speaks of a god who's as incompetent as a wagon without wheels.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A wagon needs wheels to be functional, and if it does not have wheels, it is useless.

premise: We will, gentlemen, not succeed or fail together on this, because we are too closely linked to do anything else.
hypothesis: We will, gentlemen, sink or swim together on this, because we are too closely linked to do anything else.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To sink or swim means to fail or succeed, but in this context they are saying that they will not fail or succeed together.

premise: It wrapped tightly around him until his own shield was suffocating him.
hypothesis: It curled tighter and tighter around its victim until his own shield was like a tight wrapping of cellophane.
label: Entailment
explanation: Cellophane is a material that is known for its tight wrapping qualities, suffocating the object it is wrapped around.

premise: Even though he was thin, he looked unpleasant.
hypothesis: Having a thin figure, he looked like a dry, overgrown blade of grass.
label: Entailment
explanation: An overgrown blade of grass is one that is dry and has lost its green color, indicating that it is unpleasant.

premise: I always hear crazy noises in my house.
hypothesis: I am comforted by the weird noises that come from my house at night.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Hearing weird noises around the house at night could invoke a potential danger such as a robbery or someone breaking in with malicious intent which makes someone scared rather than comforted.

premise: I missed my flight that I paid heavily for, I was so annoyed
hypothesis: I was so angry that I missed my flight and had to spend a fortune on a new ticket
label: Entailment
explanation: Missing a flight is often a very frustrating experience, especially if the flight was expensive.

premise: After you find a strange mask on the beach, you become poor and obscure.
hypothesis: After finding a strange mask on the beach, you become suddenly more like a sun-kissed popstar.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sun-kissed popstar is somebody who is famous and has a lot of money, whereas somebody who is poor and obscure is not famous and does not have a lot of money.

premise: The moon absorbed back at itself from the lake’s surface
hypothesis: The moon winked back at itself from the lake’s surface.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The moon winked back at itself means that the moon was reflecting the light which is contradicted by the suggestion that the moon absorbed back the light.

premise: My sister threw up the other day and made a huge mess.
hypothesis: My sister puked the other day and made a huge mess that made me feel disgusted
label: Entailment
explanation: Vomit is often considered to be gross and seeing someone else vomit, especially if they make a huge mess, can often trigger feelings of disgust in other people.

premise: Most of the immigrants that have come here and now successfully part of the local community.
hypothesis: The immigrants were quickly absorbed into society.
label: Entailment
explanation: This metaphor is saying that the immigrants were quickly able to become a part of the local community.

premise: His throat had gone dry .
hypothesis: His throat had gone like a shriveled-up leaf .
label: Entailment
explanation: A shriveled-up leaf is dry and papery, so it is implied that his throat had gone dry.

premise: She laughed hysterically, her hair running wild.
hypothesis: She laughed hysterically as her hair ran like a loose horse in the glistering moonlight.
label: Entailment
explanation: A horse running loose is uncontrolled and wild, similar to how her hair is running wild.

premise: They bought it for an expensive price as no one else would have it.
hypothesis: They bought it for a song because no one else would have it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To buy something for a song means to buy it for a very low price, but the sentence describes buying it for an expensive price.

premise: I found some heavily expired milk in the back of the fridge at work and it was super gross.
hypothesis: I was appalled to find this milk that expired two months ago and it made me gag
label: Entailment
explanation: The milk was heavily expired meaning that it had been two months since the milk's expiration date and so it was most likely rotten and full of bacteria which would make anyone gag.

premise: My lawyer is a kind, sensitive person.
hypothesis: My lawyer is a shark.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two statements are contradictory because it is impossible for a lawyer to be both a shark, i.e., a  ruthless, aggressive creature and a kind, sensitive person at the same time.

premise: My best friend won the lottery and just got a bunch of money and I didn't!
hypothesis: I feel terrible that my best friend just got a bunch of money and I didn't
label: Entailment
explanation: Its human nature to feel envious when someone close to you gets something that you want and didn't get yourself.

premise: I have to work all weekend when I just want to sleep and do nothing.
hypothesis: I feel so fortunate that I have to work all weekend when I just want to sleep and not do anything
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone working all weekend when they don't want to is not a fortunate feeling and implies that they are doing something they don't want to as a form of punishment.

premise: They were very hesitant when we made contact with them.
hypothesis: But when we made contact with them they were like shy kindergarteners.
label: Entailment
explanation: A shy kindergarteners is a person who is very hesitant and fearful around others, so the simile is implying that the people were acting in a similar way.

premise: Her interest in butterflies is just to show off.
hypothesis: Her interest in butterflies absorbs her completely.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two sentences contradict each other because one sentence describes a situation where the person is completely absorbed in their hobby while the other sentence describes a situation where the person has no admiration for the hobby but doing only for showing off.

premise: How can I not be mad at her when my wife wasted all my retirement money
hypothesis: I get so joyful when I think about how my wife squandered all my retirement money
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not joyful to think about how someone squandered all your retirement money because it would mean that you have no money to support yourself in retirement.

premise: Even when he was praised and celebrated, Wallace met her gaze with a level stare.
hypothesis: As calm, cool and collected as a politician, even when he was under fire, wallace met her gaze with a level stare.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be under fire means to be subject to intense criticism, but in this context Wallace is not being criticized.

premise: I smashed my finger in the door the other day and I was so upset and mad!
hypothesis: I was so mad when I smashed my finger in the door that my vision turned red
label: Entailment
explanation: When people get extremely angry, it is not uncommon for their vision to turn red.

premise: But I was, it puzzled me and gave me nothing to think about as I made my way back outside the club.
hypothesis: But I was, it perplexed me and gave me food for thought as I made my way back outside the club.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To give food for thought is to give someone something to think about, but this sentence describes the person being given nothing to think about.

premise: It was indeed my turn to be exposed to a safe and secure life.
hypothesis: It was indeed my turn to run the gauntlet.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run the gauntlet means to go through danger or other difficulties,but here speaker didn't have to go through any challenges but is rather speaking about being exposed to a safe life.

premise: I used the internet to help me write a paper once because I didn't read the literature.
hypothesis: I had to use the internet as a crutch because I am such a genius for skimming through the literature and not doing any of the reading
label: Contradiction
explanation: The internet should not be used as a crutch because it is a tool that can provide quick and easy answers to questions and therefore people who rely on it heavily are considered lazy and not geniuses.

premise: The party only began when she left.
hypothesis: The party dissipated as soon as she left.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To dissipate means to disperse or scatter, while to begin means to start or commence.

premise: I accidentally bumped into someone at the mall and they dropped their phone and the screen cracked.
hypothesis: I felt overjoyed when I accidentally bumped into someone at the mall and they dropped their phone and the screen cracked
label: Contradiction
explanation: Accidentally bumping into someone and causing them to drop their phone is not a good experience and so feeling overjoyed at the mall cannot be justified.

premise: At that point, it could spread infectiously
hypothesis: At that point, it could spread like Herpes at band camp.
label: Entailment
explanation: Herpes is a virus that is highly contagious, so the simile is emphasizing how quickly and easily the problem could spread.

premise: The waiter spilled coffee on my $1000 suit.
hypothesis: The waiter's carelessness made me furious when he spilled coffee on my $1000 suit
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is careless and they damage something that is expensive it is natural to feel angry because of the financial loss.

premise: Now she seemed insignificant't
hypothesis: Now she seemed like a buzzing fly at a picnic
label: Entailment
explanation: A fly is a small, insignificant creature that buzzes around and is generally considered a nuisance.

premise: I was really looking forward to camping but now it is going to rain so I won't go.
hypothesis: I was excited to go camping but now I don't want to go because it's going to rain
label: Entailment
explanation: Camping in the rain is often uncomfortable and not as fun as camping in good weather so if the forecast predicts rain, people who were looking forward to camping often change their minds.

premise: Every day, I work hard to put food on the table, and then I cop this from the missus.
hypothesis: day in, day out, I work hard to put food on the table, and then I cop this from the missus.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom day in, day out is used to describe something that happens routinely or regularly, which in this sentence is the hard work that the speaker does every day.

premise: There are definitely other ways to interpret it.
hypothesis: There are no two ways about it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom no two ways about it means that there is no other way to interpret it, but this context states that there are definitely other ways to interpret it.

premise: My neighbor neglects their dog.
hypothesis: It feels great to see my caring neighbor doesn't take any care of their poor dog.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The neighbor should be taking care of their dog because it is their responsibility to do so, and not doing so makes the neighbor seem uncaring and is not a great thing to witness.

premise: I am scared of another hurricane coming through Florida because I had a bad experience last year.
hypothesis: I am excited for another hurricane coming through Florida because I had a fantastic experience last year
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hurricane often causes a lot of damage and destruction and can be really dangerous, so it is not something people should be excited of but rather scared about.

premise: I tried a keto pizza yesterday and it was awful.
hypothesis: I tried a keto pizza yesterday and it was a total disaster
label: Entailment
explanation: Keto pizzas are usually made with a cauliflower crust which can often be soggy and not taste very good.

premise: There's a bad storm coming in tonight.
hypothesis: I am scared about the impending storm that's supposed to arrive tonight
label: Entailment
explanation: It is common to feel scared during a storm, especially if it is a bad one.

premise: I was feeling pretty much alone when I didn't see my boyfriend for two days.
hypothesis: I felt really valued when I didn't see my boyfriend for two days.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A relationship should involve spending time with each other and not avoiding each other so not seeing someone for two days cannot make them feel valued.

premise: My neice and daughter left such a mess in the play room today that I couldn't even look at them
hypothesis: I was so calm and happy when I came home and found the playroom in total shambles that I couldn't even look at my niece and daughter
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing the playroom in a state of disarray would usually invoke feelings of anger, frustration or disappointment in most people and so finding it in that condition does not make someone calm and happy.

premise: I woke up in the middle of the night yesterday and freaked out thinking that something crawled on me.
hypothesis: I just love the feeling of something creeping up on me in the middle of the night.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Feeling something creepy crawl up on you in the darkness of night can invoke feelings of fear and terror and is not a sensation that someone would love.

premise: The music faded to a whisper.
hypothesis: The music swelled to a crescendo.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A crescendo is a gradual increase in volume, while a whisper is a soft, gentle sound.

premise: An older woman in a class I took in college stole my ideas for a paper and presented them as her own.
hypothesis: The fact that an older woman in my college class stole my ideas for a paper and presented them as her own makes me so angry
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone steals your ideas it is a form of plagiarism and is often seen as a very serious offense, especially when done by someone who should know better like an older woman in a college class.

premise: I once took a dive into the pool and came up with no swim trunks.
hypothesis: I remember the fantastic time when I dived into the pool and came up with no swim trunks.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Diving into a pool without swim trunks can lead to someone's private parts being exposed and so it was not a good experience for them.

premise: I was disappointed when my son brought home his first F
hypothesis: I was really proud when my son brought home his first failing grade
label: Contradiction
explanation: A failing grade is not something to be proud of because it means that the son has not been doing well in school.

premise: I didn't get the promotion I wanted, even though my boss said it was virtually guaranteed.
hypothesis: I am thrilled about the fact that even though my boss said it was a guarantee, I didn't get the promotion I wanted
label: Contradiction
explanation: A promotion at work is something that people usually aspire to get and hence not getting it despite a guarantee can be very disappointing which is the opposite of being thrilled.

premise: As he ran after them, breaking backs and crushing skulls, his upper body became engulfed in a red light.
hypothesis: As he chased after them, breaking backs and crushing skulls, his upper body began to glow like a dying coal .
label: Entailment
explanation: A dying coal is red and emits a red light.

premise: It was a quick fire that burned between them.
hypothesis: It lit the fire between them like a match ignites timber.
label: Entailment
explanation: A match igniting timber is a very quick fire, so this is implying that the fire between them was a quick fire.

premise: But this other world wants to be known, it doesn't want to remain hidden.
hypothesis: But this other world doesn't want to be known, it wants to remain like an underground cult.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An underground cult is a secret society that is not known by many people, so if this other world wants to remain like an underground cult, it means it wants to stay hidden.

premise: There's nothing that ticks me off more than someone who tries too hard to make an impression.
hypothesis: I can't stand it when someone is trying too hard to be something they're not and it just makes me angry
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is trying too hard to make an impression, they are often not being genuine and authentic and this can come across as fake and irritating.

premise: I fell asleep during my date last night.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I dozed off during my date last night
label: Entailment
explanation: It is generally considered to be very rude to fall asleep during a date and so most people would feel terrible if they did.

premise: Not a married guy out looking for a quick verbal amorous play, but a man who would truly love her.
hypothesis: Not a married guy out looking for a quick slap and tickle, but a man who would truly love her.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A slap and tickle refers to physical amorous play, but the contradiction is saying that the man is looking for verbal amorous play instead.

premise: Maybe nice people were fine, and maybe you didn't have to be so submissive and unassuming all the time.
hypothesis: Maybe nice people were fine, and maybe you didn't have to throw your weight around all the time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw your weight around means to assert oneself in a controlling domineering or authoritarian manner, but the context describes being submissive and unassuming.

premise: The wildfire spread so fast through the forest to my amazement.
hypothesis: The wildfire leapt through the forest at an amazing speed.
label: Entailment
explanation: Leapt through the forest means it moved quickly through the forest.

premise: Your phone loudly interrupts your business dinner with your boss.
hypothesis: You are at a business dinner with your boss when your phone rings out like a petulant child.
label: Entailment
explanation: A petulant child is one who cries or throws tantrums loudly and interruptively.

premise: Months earlier, wade lanier had suggested, officially and formally, that the body be exhumed for toxicity tests.
hypothesis: Months earlier, wade lanier had suggested, off the record, that the body be exhumed for toxicity tests.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be off the record is to be unofficial and informal, but in this context he was official and formal.

premise: This problem has followed the UK and is now affecting them as well.
hypothesis: this problem has migrated to the uk.
label: Entailment
explanation: By migrated means the this problem has come to the UK.

premise: My wallet was stollen at work.
hypothesis: I love that someone would be so brazen to steal my wallet right at work
label: Contradiction
explanation: No one would like their wallet to be stolen from them, especially not while they are at work because it would hamper their productivity and leave them feeling upset and violated.

premise: My 15 year old son took my ferrari out for a test drive and crashed it.
hypothesis: I am utterly delighted that my 15 year old son crashed my ferrari while taking it for a test drive
label: Contradiction
explanation: A son crashing his father's car is not a good thing as it could cause harm to him, damage the car and cost a lot of money to fix.

premise: There was a hair baked into one of my raviolis , super long and not mine at all.
hypothesis: Was pleased to find an odd hair baked into one of my raviolis and it definitely was not mine
label: Contradiction
explanation: Finding a hair in food is usually considered to be gross and unappetizing, so it would not make someone pleased.

premise: I got lost and trapped in a cave.
hypothesis: Love how I got lost and then found myself trapped in a dark cave
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting lost can be a very scary experience and finding oneself trapped in a dark cave can make the situation even worse.

premise: I have very bad teeth and have to hide my smile.
hypothesis: I feel excellent that I have to hide my smile because of my terrible teeth
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone with terrible teeth would not feel excellent about having to hide their smile and instead, it would be a cause of embarrassment and self-consciousness.

premise: Guys who give an honest effort, I do not support them and do not fight for them.
hypothesis: Guys who give an honest effort, I go to the mat for them.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go to the mat for someone means to give them full support and fight for them until the end, but in this context there is no support given.

premise: The candle flame was stagnated.
hypothesis: The candle flame twirled in the dark.
label: Contradiction
explanation: When a candle twirled, it is flickering whereas when the flame appears to be stagnated is stands still.

premise: They were azure blue .
hypothesis: They were like a clear, cloudless summer sky .
label: Entailment
explanation: A cloudless summer sky is typically a very deep blue color.

premise: It is all hard work raising a child, you know.
hypothesis: Its not all fun and games raising a child, you know.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To say it's not all fun and games means that there is more to something than just playing around, but in this sentence raising a child is described as hard work.

premise: The surface of Mars was blossoming beautifully
hypothesis: The surface of Mars was blossoming like the Garden of Eden.
label: Entailment
explanation: The Garden of Eden was a paradise, so the surface of Mars blossoming like it would indicate that it was blossoming beautifully.

premise: I'm feeling pretty bummed after seeing a photo of myself 4 years ago I gained so much weight!
hypothesis: After seeing a photo of myself from 4 years ago I feel so pleased for having gained so much weight.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone gaining weight over a period of 4 years is not something to be pleased about but instead, ashamed of.

premise: The conversation was very juicy.
hypothesis: The conversation was as juicy as a business meeting
label: Contradiction
explanation: A business meeting would not be considered a juicy conversation because it would be about work and not personal matters.
