premise: I broke my laptop screen yesterday and now I am out a hundred bucks to get it fixed!
hypothesis: I feel very cheerful because I broke my laptop screen and now have to spend a hundred bucks to get it fixed
label: Contradiction
explanation: Breaking a laptop screen is not something that would make someone feel cheerful because it is an expensive thing to fix and can cause a lot of inconvenience.

premise: My upstairs neighbor moved out recently and blocked the parking space by leaving all her trash and furniture there.
hypothesis: I'm so happy that my upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space
label: Contradiction
explanation: The fact that the upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space is really inconsiderate and not something to be happy for.

premise: Rather, he walked past maris and entered the reception room so that he could open the bar and yank a bottle of tondarion fire that was readily available for purchase.
hypothesis: Rather, he walked past maris and entered the reception room so that he could open the bar and yank a bottle of tondarion fire off the shelf.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be off the shelf means to be ready made for purchase, and in this context a bottle of tondarion fire is readily available for purchase.

premise: Only those with their feet on rock can make plans that are very achievable and realistic.
hypothesis: Only those with their feet on rock can build castles in the air.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To build castles in the air means to make plans that can never come true, but this sentence is saying that only those who are grounded can make plans that are achievable and realistic.

premise: During the conflict the first elements of a peace accord appeared.
hypothesis: During the conflict the seeds of peace were planted.
label: Entailment
explanation: Just as it takes time for seeds to grow into plants, it takes time for the first elements of a peace accord to develop into a full-fledged agreement.

premise: I ordered a nice breakfast for me and my kids this morning and they got everything wrong!
hypothesis: I am so happy that my breakfast order got messed up and my kids didn't get what they wanted.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be happy if their breakfast order got messed up and their kids didn't get what they wanted, but here the speaker is pretending to be happy about it which shows that they are not actually pleased.

premise: I never got involved with anyone who was married or too young or too naive to know about the pleasures of life and its beautiful moments.
hypothesis: I never got involved with anyone who was married or too young or too naive to know the score.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To know the score means to know the facts about life and its difficulties, but in this context the speaker is saying she never got involved with people who were naive to know about pleasures of life and its beautiful moments but not life and its difficulties.

premise: He may continuously become more successful or improved, in the life of perfect service.
hypothesis: He may go from strength to strength, in the life of perfect service.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go from strength to strength means to become increasingly successful or improved, which is what he may do in the life of perfect service.

premise: Mella orders, while bobbing her skull up and down several times a big problem she thinks.
hypothesis: Mella orders, while bobbing her skull up and down several times ,no sweat she thinks.
label: Contradiction
explanation: No sweat means not a problem or difficulty, but in this context it is a big problem for her to orders while bobbing her skull.

premise: My son had an ingrown toenail so I took him to the podiatrist today.
hypothesis: Taking my son to the podiatrist today to get his ingrown toenail removed was pretty fun
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having an ingrown toenail removed is not a fun experience for anyone and is often painful.

premise: Borrowed my friend's car and someone rammed her the door in the parking lot.
hypothesis: Borrowed my friend's car and am feeling terrible that someone rammed her the door in the parking lot
label: Entailment
explanation: When you borrow a friend's car you are responsible for taking care of it as if it were your own and so if something happens to it, like someone ramming into the door, the person who borrowed it is likely to feel terrible.

premise: I expected lemus to act rashly and recklessly without consideration, but he was firing aimlessly without holsters now.
hypothesis: I expected lemus to shoot from the hip, but he was firing aimlessly without holsters now.
label: Entailment
explanation: To shoot from the hip means to act rashly and recklessly without consideration, which is what lemus was doing when he was firing aimlessly.

premise: She was not modest
hypothesis: She was as modest as Lady Godiva
label: Entailment
explanation: Lady Godiva is a well-known figure for her act of riding naked through the streets and hence would not be modest at all.

premise: The causes of progress are in technological development.
hypothesis: The roots of progress are in technological development.
label: Entailment
explanation: By roota of progress it means the reason of the progress.

premise: I felt bad for not taking a gift to a party i went to yesterday
hypothesis: I felt bad for not taking a gift to the party I attended yesterday and making everyone feel awkward
label: Entailment
explanation: It is considered polite to take a gift when attending a party and not doing so often makes people feel awkward because they feel like they should have brought something.

premise: Today, Carly wanted to feel like she was powerless.
hypothesis: But today carly wanted to feel like a kick-ass chick in a superhero movie.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A kick-ass chick is somebody who is powerful and in control, whereas feeling powerless would be the opposite.

premise: My boyfriend broke up with me.
hypothesis: I feel really lonely because my boyfriend just broke up with me
label: Entailment
explanation: When people are in a relationship they often feel less lonely because they have someone to share their life with but when that relationship ends they often feel a sense of loneliness because they are now alone.

premise: I felt leftout when I was in a train yesterday
hypothesis: I felt like an outsider when I was in a train yesterday filled with so many people.
label: Entailment
explanation: When a person feels left out or like an outsider in a situation they are often feeling isolated and alone.

premise: My favorite team blew a big lead in the playoffs.
hypothesis: My favorite team totally choked in the playoffs and it makes me feel sick
label: Entailment
explanation: People often feel betrayed when their favorite team loses after having a big lead because it seems like the team gave up or choked and it is very disappointing.

premise: The notion of loving too much seemed cynical and unromantic
hypothesis: The notion of loving too much seemed like a real-life wuthering heights with heathcliff crying out his anguish to the windswept moors.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Wuthering Heights is a novel about an intense, passionate love so in the simile the notion of loving too much is being compared to something that is wildly romantic  and not cynical or unromantic.

premise: I was at a party with my boyfriend, and he seemed to be ignoring me.
hypothesis: I was at a party with my boyfriend and he ignoring me there made me super envious
label: Entailment
explanation: If someone is ignoring their significant other in a social setting like a party it often makes the person being ignored feel jealous and envious.

premise: After several ales in one pleasant drinking abode caradas resumed his search but had to look much further and in many other places than the second tavern he went into.
hypothesis: After several ales in one pleasant drinking abode caradas resumed his search but need look no further than the second tavern he went into.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To look no further means that something is exactly what someone wants or needs, but this context describes having to look in many other places.

premise: Hell with it, he thinks, I'm not going to give this my all.
hypothesis: Hell with it, he thinks, go for broke.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go for broke means to give something one's full effort, but in this sentence he decides not to give it his all.

premise: I totaled my brand new car yesterday.
hypothesis: I feel excited that my brand new car is totaled and now completely wrecked
label: Contradiction
explanation: A brand new car being totaled is a really bad thing because it means the car is now completely unusable and has no value.

premise: I got the worst mark back on my science test.
hypothesis: I am such a star academic for getting the worst possible grade back on my science test
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting the worst possible grade is not something to be happy about and it certainly does not make someone a star academic.

premise: Each stride he took was long
hypothesis: Each stride he took was like a tennis court.
label: Entailment
explanation: A tennis court is a large expanse of space, so each stride he took must have been long.

premise: Turns out, tag between super heroes can get pretty tame.
hypothesis: Turns out, tag between super heroes can get like a sibling rivalry.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sibling rivalry is characterized by competition and conflict, whereas something that is tame is not characterized by those qualities.

premise: My old hard drive that had a lot of pictures on it went out on me.
hypothesis: I was really grateful when my old hard drive that had a lot of cherished pictures on it suddenly stopped working
label: Contradiction
explanation: Hard drives usually break down without any prior warning and hence it can be really frustrating when all the data stored on it is lost, especially if it contained cherished pictures which cannot be replaced.

premise: It made Gabe feel something strong.
hypothesis: It filled gabe with something like a heroin rush.
label: Entailment
explanation: A heroin rush is an intense feeling, so the simile sentence is saying that the thing made Gabe feel very strongly.

premise: My face was expressive.
hypothesis: My face was like an empty plate .
label: Contradiction
explanation: An empty plate has no expression, so saying that my face was like an empty plate would mean that my face was not expressive.

premise: My friend's girlfriend cheated on him.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that my friend's girlfriend cheated on him
label: Entailment
explanation: It is generally seen as morally wrong to cheat on your partner and so finding out that a friend's girlfriend has cheated on him is likely to result in feeling sympathy and sadness for the friend.

premise: She loudly landed after her cloak billowed around her and then vanished in a whirl of light.
hypothesis: Her billowing cloak vanishes in a whirl of light, allowing her to land like a fresh leaf in a still pond.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A fresh leaf falling into a still pond would make barely a splash, whereas a loud landing would make a big splash.

premise: You couldn't order right in a dennys after giving it some thought and consideration .
hypothesis: You couldn't order right off the top of your head in a dennys.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To order off the top of your head means to do it from memory or without much consideration, but in this context it talks of speakers incapability of ordering at Denny's after giving it some thought.

premise: There's this girl at work that I like, and I just saw her eating lunch with another guy and now I'm kind of sad
hypothesis: There's this girl at work that I like and I just saw her eating lunch with another guy and I suddenly feel so secure of romantic prospects with her.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone likes a girl and sees her eating lunch with another guy, it would not make them feel secure of their romantic prospects but rather would make them feel jealous and worried that the girl might like the other guy more.

premise: he was flying high happy and joy.
hypothesis: he was feeling down hurt and sad.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two statements appear to be contradictory, it is not possible to feel both happiness and sadness, or to feel both down and up, at the same time.

premise: Krishna gets up very early in the morning.
hypothesis: Krishna is an early bird.
label: Entailment
explanation: Early bird means the person who wakes up early in the morning.

premise: Adie's in trouble.
hypothesis: Adie's in dutch.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be in dutch means to be in trouble or disfavor, so Adie being in dutch means that he is in trouble.

premise: I wanted him to stop with all of that and just remain uptight and not have any fun tonight.
hypothesis: I wanted him to stop with all of that and just cut loose tonight.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cut loose means to behave in a relaxed or uninhibited manner, but in this sentence she wanted him to remain uptight.

premise: The house is pretty
hypothesis: The house is as pretty as a sunset
label: Entailment
explanation: A sunset is a very pretty sight, so the simile is saying that the house is just as pretty.

premise: They are doing construction next door and they woke me up early on my day off so annoying
hypothesis: The construction workers next door woke me up early on my day off and it's really irritating
label: Entailment
explanation: Construction workers often make a lot of noise which can be disruptive to people who are trying to sleep and if it happens on a day when someone is supposed to be resting it can be especially annoying.

premise: I failed my Introduction to Statistics class and was very nervous of having to retake it again
hypothesis: I was very discouraged when I found out I failed my Introduction to Statistics class and had to retake it again
label: Entailment
explanation: Failing a class is never a good feeling and it's especially discouraging when it's a class that is required for graduation.

premise: He told her about his marriage which was still legally binding, but was in every sense functionally over.
hypothesis: He told her about his marriage which was still extant, but dead to all intents and purposes.
label: Entailment
explanation: To all intents and purposes means in every practical or functional sense, and in this context the marriage is practically and functionally over even though it is still legally binding.

premise: I'm signed up to go sky diving for the first time this weekend but I am nervous.
hypothesis: I am not at all anxious about the fact that I am going to be jumping out of a freaking airplane for the first time this weekend.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The experience of jumping out of an airplane is usually associated with a lot of fear and anxiety, so someone who claims to not be anxious about it is absurd.

premise: Guskewau , the darkness,  exposed  her.
hypothesis: Guskewau , the darkness ,  wrapped  her.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Wrapped means that the darkness was surrounding her, while another sentence is saying that the darkness exposed her.

premise: The sudden boom in the market is mostly due to these operations .
hypothesis: The market is being clogged by these operations.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The word clogged is used as a metaphor to mean something that is blocked or hindered, while boom typically means something that is flourishing or growing rapidly.

premise: When I moved into my apartment it was full of bugs
hypothesis: I was so delighted when I moved into my apartment and found it crawling with bugs.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Bugs are usually disgusting and most people are terrified of them therefore it is unlikely to love seeing someone's apartment infested by them.

premise: I just went past a fish market, and the smell was overwhelming.
hypothesis: I drove past a fish market and the smell made me feel like I was in heaven.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Fish markets are often known for their pungent smell and so someone who says that the smell made them feel like they were in heaven is not being truthful.

premise: The surviving commoners who care a great deal about it.
hypothesis: The surviving commoners who do not give a darn about it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To give a darn means to care at all about someone or something, but in this sentence the commoners care a great deal.

premise: My friend used my car all day today and didnt even put any gas in it.
hypothesis: Pleased with how my friend borrowed my car and totally drained the gas tank without even putting any gas in it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be pleased if their friend borrowed their car and then damaged it in some way and so the speaker is using sarcasm to convey that they are not happy at all.

premise: I've been riding in a very limited space for the last ten hours, he said, taking the cloth from her and tossing it onto the bed.
hypothesis: I've been riding up hill and down dale for the last ten hours,he said, taking the cloth from her and tossing it onto the bed.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To ride up hill and down dale means to ride all over the area, but this context describes riding in a very limited space.

premise: He was convinced they knew nothing about him.
hypothesis: He was worried they might spill everything about him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The speaker is worried that the other people might spill everything about him because he has something to hide, which is contradictory to the next statement that assures he is also convinced that they know nothing about him.

premise: I found a long grey hair in my sandwitch this afternoon when I went out to lunch.
hypothesis: I was totally horrified when I found a long grey hair in my sandwich this afternoon
label: Entailment
explanation: It is usually considered very unhygienic to find hair in food, especially somebody else's hair, and so it is natural to feel horrified when this happens.

premise: Don't change my words.
hypothesis: Don't remix my words.
label: Entailment
explanation: Remixing someone's words is changing what they said to make it sound like something else entirely.

premise: The news hit me hard
hypothesis: The news hit me like a Mack truck.
label: Entailment
explanation: A Mack truck is a large, heavy vehicle, so the news hitting someone like a Mack truck would imply that it hit them very hard.

premise: She brushed her too long, severely straight bangs out of her eyes, and gave him what could only be described as a ugly and repulsive gaze.
hypothesis: She brushed her too long, severely straight bangs out of her eyes, and gave him what could only be described as bedroom eyes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To give someone bedroom eyes is to give them a sultry and suggestive gaze, but in this sentence she gave him an ugly and repulsive gaze.

premise: When I was at gym, I was bothered by the fact that my pants had torn from behind.
hypothesis: I was really proud to show my rear end when my pants suddenly ripped from the back while I was at the gym
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would feel really embarrassed and bothered if their pants ripped while they were at the gym in front of other people and would not be proud at all.

premise: I understand," she said quietly.
hypothesis: i see it now," she said, her voice like a breeze rustling through the wildflowers.
label: Entailment
explanation: The explanation for this simile is that both a breeze and someone's voice can be gentle and quiet.

premise: I hope your situation is under control.
hypothesis: I hope your situation is in hand.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be in hand means to be stable and controlled, which is what is hoped for in this sentence.

premise: My wife has made me go on a diet and I have been cheating.
hypothesis: I feel great that I am not following my wife's diet instructions and instead am cheating
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not want to break the diet instructions given to them by their spouse and so doing so makes the person feel like they are not good enough.

premise: I have tried three different times to complete a work task and each time I have failed.
hypothesis: I have failed three times to complete a work task and each time it feels like my world is crashing down
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel like someone's world is crashing down after failing to complete a task three times, especially if the task is work related.

premise: She knew she was making a total fool of herself.
hypothesis: She knew she was burning in shame.
label: Entailment
explanation: Burning in shame means she was feeling so embarrassed that it was like she was on fire.

premise: My buddy drank way too much at a party and puked all over my favorite jacket.
hypothesis: The grossest thing that happened to me this weekend was when my buddy vomited all over my favorite jacket
label: Entailment
explanation: Vomit is generally considered to be a gross and unpleasant substance so having it all over a favorite jacket would be one of the grossest things to happen to someone over the weekend.

premise: Sariel was pretty much obese
hypothesis: Sariel was like a long distance runner or swimmer.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A long distance runner or swimmer is someone who is in excellent physical shape, so saying Sariel is like them contradicts the fact that she is obese.

premise: Man, he missed the mark completely when he said that.
hypothesis: Man, he hit the nail on the head pretty close there.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To hit the nail on the head is to do something in the most effective and efficient way, but in this context he missed the mark completely.

premise: I bought a lottery ticket and did not win anything
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I wasted my money on a lottery ticket and did not even win a penny
label: Entailment
explanation: Lottery tickets are often seen as a waste of money because the chances of winning are so low and people often feel terrible after buying a ticket and not winning anything.

premise: He was fragile
hypothesis: He was like a butterfly in autumn, waiting to be destroyed by the first frost.
label: Entailment
explanation: Butterflies in autumn are waiting to be destroyed because they are fragile and won't survive the frost.

premise: I hate when my kids leave their clothes all over the floor
hypothesis: It drives me up the wall when my kids leave their clothes all over the floor
label: Entailment
explanation: It is very annoying when kids leave their clothes all over the floor because it makes the house look messy and it's hard to clean around them.

premise: It deceived from truth alone , the truth we live.
hypothesis: It struck from truth alone , the truth we live.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To strike from truth means to be based in reality or to be honest, while to deceive from truth means to be based in lies or to be dishonest.

premise: She lumbered to him, clumsily
hypothesis: She glided to him, like a ballet dancer.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A ballet dancer is light on their feet and moves gracefully, whereas someone who lumbers is heavy and moves awkwardly.

premise: My sister in law and her fiance are taking all these trips abroad and we are struggling just to get our bills paid.
hypothesis: It's making me feel terrible how my sister in law and her fiance are able to go on all these trips abroad when we're just struggling to get our bills paid
label: Entailment
explanation: Seeing other people succeed while you are struggling can be very hard and often makes people feel terrible.

premise: You have no idea why people suddenly have become healthy.
hypothesis: You have no idea why people suddenly have become like lepers.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A leper is someone who has a severe, contagious disease, so the simile is implying that the people have become diseased, not healthy.

premise: Her leg was hairy
hypothesis: Her leg was as hairy as a baby's bottom
label: Contradiction
explanation: A baby's bottom is not hairy, so saying that her leg was as hairy as a baby's bottom would imply that it is not hairy at all.

premise: My friend broke my phone that I had worked hard to buy
hypothesis: My friend broke my phone that I just saved up to buy and now I'm overjoyed.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A person's phone is often very important to them and so breaking it would be a terrible thing, which is not expressed by the use of the word overjoyed.

premise: My neighbor keeps making noise at 2 in the morning.
hypothesis: I am not happy about the fact that my neighbor is being so disruptive at 2 in the morning when everyone is trying to sleep?
label: Entailment
explanation: Making noise at night is often disruptive to other people who are trying to sleep and so it is understandable to not be happy about a neighbor who is doing this.

premise: It seemed from truth alone , the truth we live
hypothesis: It struck from truth alone , the truth we live.
label: Entailment
explanation: To strike from truth means to be based in reality, often what is seem is to appear to the eye or mind.

premise: I saw people eating live worms.
hypothesis: It was just visually amazing to see people swallowing live worms
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not find it visually amazing to see others swallowing live worms and instead would feel disgusted.

premise: She was the bleakness of my life.
hypothesis: She was the darling of my life.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two statements are contradictory because one says she was the beloved person and the other says she was the bleakness.

premise: He should have been driving away by now, but instead he was here, active.
hypothesis: He should be in his car now, driving away, and yet here he was, like a fly caught in a spiderweb.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A fly caught in a spiderweb is immobilized by the poison and the web, so he was inert and not active.

premise: The kid was a brute and noisy
hypothesis: The kid was a brute and like a locomotive.
label: Entailment
explanation: A locomotive is a large, noisy machine, so the simile is emphasizing the kid's size and noise level.

premise: You were the scapegoat of those times.
hypothesis: You were the golden boy back then.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A golden boy is someone who is favored or successful, while a scapegoat is someone who is blamed or persecuted.

premise: The decor was lavish and well-organized.
hypothesis: The decor was like a college dorm room furnished on a budget.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A college dorm room is typically small, cramped, and not well-organized or decorated, in contrast to a lavish room.

premise: I am angry that the person I live with still doesn't like paying bills.
hypothesis: It really makes me happy when the person I live with still doesn't want to pay bills on time
label: Contradiction
explanation: The person living with someone else should be contributing to bills equally and on time, so someone who still doesn't want to do that is not really happy about the situation.

premise: At a shop a seller was lying about the prices of the items that he was selling.
hypothesis: The fact that the seller blatantly lied about the prices of the items he was selling totally didn't make me angry
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone is caught lying about the prices of the items they are selling, it is not a good sign that they can be trusted and so the seller's trustworthiness is called into question.

premise: It was if she were stuck in something viscous and gluey, but she was still pushing as hard as she could.
hypothesis: She was still pushing as hard as she could, but it was as if she were like a woolly mammoth caught in an infinitely deep tar pit.
label: Entailment
explanation: A woolly mammoth stuck in an infinitely deep tar pit  means as if it were stuck in something viscous and gluey, and would not be able to move.

premise: He had risen from the bench to bid the mason farewell, and now he stood privately and confidentially under the rose trellis, which had lately come into bloom.
hypothesis: He had risen from the bench to bid the mason farewell, and now he stood under the rose trellis, which had lately come into bloom.
label: Entailment
explanation: To stand under the rose means to stand privately or confidentially, which is what he did when he bid the mason farewell.

premise: Do your own thing and we'll make great progress.
hypothesis: Synchronise your efforts or we 'll just go round in circles.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go round in circles means to waste time and not make any progress, but doing your own thing will lead to great progress.

premise: Let's just keep going and not stop here.
hypothesis: Let's just leave it at that.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To leave it at that means to take no further action, but in this context they are suggesting to keep going and not stop.

premise: His nose was rather wide.
hypothesis: His nose was like a branch jutting from a tree.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A branch jutting from a tree is typically thin, not wide, since it extends over the main body of the tree.

premise: The wheel has gone off its axis and everything changed now.
hypothesis: The wheel has come full circle.
label: Contradiction
explanation: One statement here is suggesting that something has gone wrong and everything has changed as a result whereas one statement is saying that everything is back to the way it was before.

premise: A friend let me borrow some of his old headphones and now I have lost them.
hypothesis: A friend let me borrow his old headphones and now I feel terrible that I lost them
label: Entailment
explanation: Losing something that someone else let you borrow is often seen as very disrespectful and careless so it would make sense for someone to feel terrible after losing something that wasn't even theirs to begin with.

premise: His hand slid up, fingertips brushing against lace and- his cell phone went off in his pocket loud and shrilling
hypothesis: His hand slid up, fingertips brushing against lace and- his cell phone went off in his pocket like a fire alarm.
label: Entailment
explanation: A fire alarm is a loud and shrilling noise, so the simile is emphasizing how loud and shrilling the cell phone went off.

premise: I was cut off today and crashed my car into a pole to avoid colliding with someone.
hypothesis: I was so overjoyed when I got cut off that I celebrated by crashing my car into a pole to avoid colliding with someone
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being cut off by another driver is often a very frustrating thing and can cause road rage and, it would not make anyone overjoyed and instead cause them to act out in anger.

premise: The charges were exaggerated.
hypothesis: The charges were inflated.
label: Entailment
explanation: Inflated means to increase in size or value.

premise: My dog pooped on the carpet yesterday.
hypothesis: I am so happy about the fact that my dog pooped on the carpet yesterday
label: Contradiction
explanation: A dog pooping on the carpet is a very dirty and unsanitary thing to do and so someone cannot be proud of it .

premise: My son raided the snack cupboard before dinnertime, eating all my favourite snacks, and he made a mess out of it.
hypothesis: My son ate all my favorite snacks before dinner which was great and he made things even better by making a huge mess of the cupboard in the process.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A child eating all of someone's favorite snacks before dinner is not a good thing because it leaves them with nothing to eat and also creates a mess.

premise: My brother calls me all the time I can't stand it.
hypothesis: The fact that my brother calls me all the time and I can't seem to get a break from him makes me annoyed
label: Entailment
explanation: If someone is constantly being called by someone else and they can't seem to get a break from them it is only natural to feel annoyed by the situation.

premise: My head was in the middle of a triangle made by her neck and both her shoulders.
hypothesis: My head dwelled in the crook of her neck.
label: Entailment
explanation: The phrase to be in the crook of someone's neck means to be resting in the space between their neck and shoulder.

premise: For a while it was unclear and uncertain.
hypothesis: For a while it was touch and go.
label: Entailment
explanation: Touch and go refers to something being uncertain, and in this context it is uncertain as to the outcome.

premise: I was so afraid of going in my barn because I got stung by a wasp last year in my neck.
hypothesis: I love going in my barn because I got stung by a wasp last year and it hurt so much.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The experience of getting stung by a wasp is usually very painful and so going into a barn, which is likely to have wasps again, is not something that someone would love.

premise: The judge will want to charge and convict you with the minimum number of crimes.
hypothesis: The judge will want to throw the book at you.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw the book at someone means to charge or convict them with as many crimes as possible, but the judge in this context wants to do the opposite.

premise: Your wife told you last night that lucid dreams are quite common.
hypothesis: Last night you learned from your wife that lucid dreams are like hen's teeth.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The simile is saying that lucid dreams are very rare, like hen's teeth, which are not found often.

premise: The clientele was nicely mixed between people who were wearing clothes and those who were not.
hypothesis: The clientele was nicely mixedtown and gown.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Town and gown refers to the two distinct communities of a university town, but this context is mixing people who are clothed and those who are not.

premise: I recently had a wonderful experience with a woman I really like, the night ended poorly and I came across very disappointed with the ending.
hypothesis: I had a great time with the woman I like but the night ended abruptly and that makes me really joyful
label: Contradiction
explanation: A night ending abruptly is not a good thing because it means that either the two people involved did not have a good time or something bad happened and hence the person should not feel swell about it.

premise: Having uncooked meat in a fatty gravy is gross.
hypothesis: The meat was transfigured in a fatty gravy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To transfigure something means to change or transform it, while having uncooked meat in a fatty gravy would suggest that it has not been changed or transformed in any way.

premise: All of my friends aren't speaking to me and I don't know why.
hypothesis: I feel really cared for right now because all my friends stopped talking to me and I don't know why
label: Contradiction
explanation: When friends stop talking to someone, withou any specified reason it makes them feel neglected and not cared for.

premise: I was so furious when my coworker badmouthed me to my boss.
hypothesis: I was so angry when my coworker tattled on me to my boss
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone talks badly about you to your boss it is often seen as a betrayal and can make you very angry.

premise: I can never get a good answer out of my wife where she wants to go eat and this past time it just rubbed me the wrong way.
hypothesis: The fact that my wife couldn't just tell me a straight answer about where she wanted to eat made me so happy to be her husband.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The wife not giving a straight answer about where to eat shows that she is indecisive and likely to change her mind often, which can be frustrating for the husband.

premise: We went the full distance to portland, even though the brunswick mall is only a half-hour away.
hypothesis: We go all the way to portland, even though the brunswick mall is only a half-hour away.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go all the way means to continue on a course to the end, which is what they did by going to Portland.

premise: One time I sweat so much on the way to the store that I had a big sweat stain on my butt!
hypothesis: The one time I went to the store and had a sweat stain on my butt from sweating so much was pretty comforting
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having a sweat stain on your butt from sweating is an embarrassing and unpleasant experience that nobody would want to go through and hence it cannot be pretty comforting.

premise: When I came back from my vacation, I was horrified when I found that there is a rat in my garden.
hypothesis: When I came back from my vacation, I was elated when I found that there is a rat in my garden
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having a rat in the garden is not a blessed feeling because rats are usually considered to be pests and they can ruin plants and gardens.

premise: My ex girlfriend cheated on me with one of my closest friends.
hypothesis: I totally understand how my ex girlfriend could cheat on me with one of my closest friends
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is unlikely that someone's ex girlfriend cheating on them with one of their close friends would be understandable because it breaks the trust which is usually present in those types of relationships.

premise: Yesterday I wasn't paying attention while driving and almost hit a person in a crosswalk.
hypothesis: Yesterday I was driving and really concentrating as hard as I could which I why I almost hit a pedestrian.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Hitting a pedestrian is really dangerous and so it cannot be justified by saying that the driver was concentrating hard.

premise: I ate my husbands leftovers while he was asleep
hypothesis: I believe in sharing is caring so I ate my husbands leftovers while he was snoring away in the bedroom.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The saying sharing is caring usually means sharing something with someone who needs or wants it, not taking something away from them while they're sleeping.

premise: They never said that they are germans.
hypothesis: they never mentioned being germans.
label: Entailment
explanation: This is a metaphor meaning that the person was never upfront about their nationality and kept it hidden.

premise: The love of my life left me for a better man.
hypothesis: The love of my life left me for someone richer, better looking, and more successful than me
label: Entailment
explanation: It is common for people to leave their partner for someone who is better in some way than them whether that be in terms of looks, money, or success.

premise: My younger brother always get the best dates and beautiful girls to date,i hate it.
hypothesis: Luckily for me, my younger brother always manages to get the prettiest girls to date while I get to remain single
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not good luck when someone manages to get prettier girls to date than oneself, but instead indicates that the person is not as attractive.

premise: I want my friends newly purchased BMW car so bad it hurts!
hypothesis: It doesn't make me feel bad at all that my friend purchased a BMW, something I can only think of buying in my wildest dreams.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A BMW is a very expensive car and so someone who can only think of buying it in their wildest dreams cannot afford it, which should make them feel bad.

premise: make the information known to as many people as possible.
hypothesis: spread the word.
label: Entailment
explanation: To spread the word means to disseminate a specific piece of information to as many people as possible.

premise: There are fewer people who want to be in charge than there are people willing to do the work.
hypothesis: It's kind of like there are too many chiefs and not enough indians
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom means that there are too many people who want to be in charge, but this context suggests that there are fewer people who want to be in charge.

premise: Kyle's latest throw was right on target and very accurate.
hypothesis: Kyle's latest throw was off the mark.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be off the mark means to be inaccurate or wrong, but in this context Kyle's latest throw was both accurate and on target.

premise: Oh , and there 's one more thing you can be sure of ,, he added cheerfully.
hypothesis: Oh , and there 's one more thing you can be sure of , ’ he added sourly .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Something that is added sourly would be done with a negative or bitter attitude, while something that is added cheerfully would be done with a positive or happy attitude.

explanation: Homeless people are often associated with poverty and desperation and seeing them in such a state would not lead to feeling like its a beautiful sight but rather an upleasant and upsetting sight.

hypothesis: Despite all the other turmoil in my life, just the thought of seeing bo made me like a caffeine junkie.
label: Entailment
explanation: A caffeine junkie is someone who is addicted to coffee and experiences withdrawal symptoms when they do not have it, so the simile implies the person was jittery with anticipation wants to see Bo.

premise: Your head will become clear after 10 minutes.
hypothesis: After 10 minutes your head becomes like spinning cotton candy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spinning cotton candy is a process of quickly spinning sugar to create a light, fluffy mass, so their head would seem more fuzzy than clear.

premise: With each lap of the waves against the hull, tony closed off insidious emotions before they could take effect inside him and focused on the shore.
hypothesis: With each lap of the waves against the hull, tony closed off insidious emotions before they could take root inside him and focused on the shore.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take root means to begin to take hold or have effect, and in this context the emotions are being closed off before they can take effect.

premise: Till it acquired the form and features.
hypothesis: Till it took the form and features.
label: Entailment
explanation: Took means to get or to receive something, so, in this case, the thing that is being received is the form and features of something.

premise: It is wrong to lie to children.
hypothesis: Telling lies to the young is like clippin the wings of a butterfly.
label: Entailment
explanation: Clipping the wings of a butterfly prevents it from being able to fly, in the same way that lying to children prevents them from being able to develop and grow in an uninhibited way.

premise: I was traveling internationally literally the day after a high level travel alert was issued for the region I was going.
hypothesis: I wasn't fazed at that the high level travel alert would interrupt my travel to the region because the thought of being killed is just so exciting.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Receive a high level travel alert for a region means that there is a potential danger in traveling to that place and so the excitement mentioned cannot be justified.

premise: I was pissed at the fact that my landlord entered my appartment without notifying me.
hypothesis: I was livid when my landlord entered my apartment without notifying me
label: Entailment
explanation: It is a violation of privacy for someone to enter your home without letting you know first and so it is understandable to be very angry when it happens.

premise: Everytime I try to eat dinner a salesman calls me on the phone.
hypothesis: I just love it when I am trying to have dinner and a salesman calls me on the phone.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dinner is usually a time when people want to be left alone and hence getting a call from a salesman is really disruptive.

premise: I ordered a limited editon tshirt from my favorite band and they sent the wrong size
hypothesis: I am so happy that the band sent me the wrong size for the limited edition shirt I ordered
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone ordered a limited edition item, they would want it to be perfect and in the right size, so receiving the wrong size would not make them feel happy.

premise: Now you can go crazy if you want, or get jesus, or get drunk but you saw what you saw and leave us not add any more unnecessary embellishments, all right?
hypothesis: Now you can go crazy if you want, or get jesus, or get drunk but you saw what you saw and leave us not gild the lily, all right?
label: Entailment
explanation: To gild the lily means to add unnecessary embellishments to something that is already beautiful, but in this sentence they are asking to not add any more embellishments.

premise: This headache needs to go away.
hypothesis: I don't know how much longer I can put up with this headache
label: Entailment
explanation: Headaches can be extremely painful and disruptive so it's often hard to endure them for long periods of time.

premise: I'd do anything to go back to you just being an amazing actor that I worshipped and saw as perfect.
hypothesis: I'd give anything to go back to you just being an amazing actor that I put on a pedestal.
label: Entailment
explanation: To put on a pedestal means to see someone or something as perfect, and in this context the speaker wants to go back to seeing the actor as perfect.

premise: Monty was completely penniless.
hypothesis: Monty swam in a sea of diamonds.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sea of diamonds would be a vast and endless wealth, while being penniless suggests that Monty was poverty-sticken.

premise: The harsh criticism of his work made him ecstatic.
hypothesis: The bad review of his work deflated his self-confidence.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Ecstatic means to be in a state of intense happiness or joy, while deflated means to have one's spirits lowered or diminished.

premise: My instincts allowed him to be very considerate and respectful of my feelings this afternoon.
hypothesis: My instincts let him run roughshod over my feelings this afternoon.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run roughshod over something is to act without regard for it, but in this context the person's instincts allowed for the opposite to happen and his feelins were respected.

premise: The city of Philadelphia lay just out of sight; he could smell the haze of fire, the stink of thousands of people living far away from each other.
hypothesis: The city of Philadelphia lay just out of sight; he could smell the haze of fire, the stink of thousands of people living cheek by jowl.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be cheek by jowl is to be positioned very close together, but in this sentence the people are living far away from each other.

premise: I hate it when the waitress bring another table food when I got there first
hypothesis: I just love it when the waitress brings food to another table when I am the one who got there first.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is very frustrating to wait for your food and see someone else getting it instead, so the sentiment expressed by the speaker is not one of love but annoyance.

premise: Her mother had reminded her that it is not important to take care of your own family and friends before helping others.
hypothesis: Her mother had reminded her that charity begins at home.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom charity begins at home means that one should help family and close friends before helping others, but in this sentence her mother was saying the opposite.

premise: Valentinos mind was garbled
hypothesis: Valentinos mind was like a spilled box of beads bouncing in every direction.
label: Entailment
explanation: A box of beads that has been spilled is no longer organized and is garbled, and is instead bouncing around chaotically.

premise: The world turned blue
hypothesis: The world turned like a fantastic voyage inside a volcano.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A volcano is red and hot on the inside, so the world turning like a volcano would imply it is red and hot, not blue.

premise: Her eyes were really tiny and bright.
hypothesis: Her eyes were fireflies.
label: Entailment
explanation: Fireflies are small insects that have bright eyes.

premise: She was saddened by his refusal of her invitation.
hypothesis: She was crushed by his refusal of her invitation.
label: Entailment
explanation: Crushed means she was very sad and disappointed by his refusal.

premise: Anastasia says, "if anybody has any suggestions, we don't want to hear."
hypothesis: Anastasia says, "if anybody has any suggestions, we are all ears."
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be all ears means to be ready and eager to hear what one has to say, but in this sentence Anastasia is saying that they don't want to hear any suggestions.

premise: She was ready and anxious to do something.
hypothesis: She was champing at the bit.
label: Entailment
explanation: To champ at the bit means to be ready and anxious to do something, which is what she was.

premise: his sensitive ears picked up every sound, it was still quiet.
hypothesis: His sensitive ears picked up every sound, but it was like a library on friday night
label: Entailment
explanation: On a Friday night, libraries are still and quiet, implying it was quiet.

premise: My friend's girlfriend cheated on him.
hypothesis: I totally feel thrilled that my friend's girlfriend cheated on him
label: Contradiction
explanation: A friend's girlfriend cheating on him is a terrible thing and so feeling elated about it is not normal.

premise: I sluggishly walk back over to my suitcase feeling displeased and unhappy.
hypothesis: I prance back over to my suitcase feeling like I'm on cloud nine.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be on cloud nine is to be in a state of extreme euphoric happiness, but this context describes feeling the opposite i.e feeling displeased and unhappy.

premise: A fun time was ruined as soon as she left the party.
hypothesis: The party died as soon as she left.
label: Entailment
explanation: The party died means that the party was no longer fun once she left.

premise: I'm waiting on some test results from the Dr. and it's taking forever.
hypothesis: I'm anxiously waiting for my test results from the doctor and really hope everything comes back normal
label: Entailment
explanation: It is common to feel anxious while waiting for test results from the doctor because there is always the worry that something could be wrong and the wait can often feel interminable.

premise: My parents always argue and it pisses me off!
hypothesis: My parents always argue and it really aggravates me to see them fight all the time!
label: Entailment
explanation: Parents arguing in front of their children can often be very upsetting and aggravating to see because it sets a bad example and can make the children feel like they are caught in the middle.

premise: You will act without considering my wellbeing for the rest of our days, I can see it already.
hypothesis: You will run roughshod over me for the rest of our days, I can see it already.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run roughshod over someone means to act without considering their wellbeing, which is what the speaker can see happening already.

premise: I eased with this decision for years.
hypothesis: I wrestled with this decision for years.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To wrestle with something means to struggle or fight with it, while to ease with something means to proceed or go along with it smoothly.

premise: You have to avoid confrontation with your fears in order to win them.
hypothesis: You have to head straight into your fears to win them.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To head straight into something means to confront it directly, while to avoid confrontation with something means to stay away from it or not face it head-on.

premise: The woman's personality was sweet.
hypothesis: The woman's personality was as sweet as a War Head
label: Contradiction
explanation: A War Head candy is very sour, so saying someone's personality is as sweet as a War Head would mean that the person's personality is very sour.

premise: I lost a good job a few years back and a consequence my kids and I also lost our home of 11 years.
hypothesis: I felt such an immense sense of relief when I lost my job and consequently our home that we had for 11 years.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing a job and consequently a home is very painful and difficult and so feeling relief at that situation is absurd.

premise: My boss didn't accept my vacation plan.
hypothesis: How cool is it that my boss just shot down my idea to take a vacation and enjoy some time off
label: Contradiction
explanation: Rejecting an employee's idea to take a vacation shows that the boss does not care about their well-being and instead values work more than rest and hence isn't cool.

premise: The phone number was so complex
hypothesis: The phone number was easy to remember as a 100 number password
label: Entailment
explanation: A 100 number password is a long, complex string of numbers, so the phone number must be similarly long and complex.

premise: I was sitting eating dinner when all of the sudden my cat jumped on the kitchen table and knocked over my food!
hypothesis: I was sitting eating dinner when my cat jumped on the kitchen table and knocked over my food! How thoughtful of him!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cats are often known to be unhygienic and jump on tables where food is present which can lead to the food being contaminated and so, when someone's cat does this, it is not thoughtful at all.

premise: Last week I accidentally dropped my brand new phone and broke it.
hypothesis: Last week I was thrilled when I accidentally dropped my brand new phone and it broke.

hypothesis: My best friend abandoned me at the bar with a random dude while I was hammered instead of getting me home
label: Entailment
explanation: Being abandoned at a bar by your best friend while you are drunk and with a random stranger is pretty scary and not something that a good friend would do.

premise: She had the same green eyes as her mother and Abram Von Helrung.
hypothesis: Like her mother, she had abram von helrung's eyes, like a mountain lake on a sunny autumn day.
label: Contradiction

label: Entailment

premise: My neighbors dog does not shut up at night and it's agitating me.
hypothesis: I am so happy because my neighbors dog barks all freaking night and it's really restoring my sanity.
label: Contradiction

premise: I was counting on a loan from  the bank and I just found out I cant get it.

label: Entailment

premise: One of my favorite restaurants that I frequent weekly was just shut down by the health department.
hypothesis: I feel so reassured that my favorite restaurant got shut down by the health department for having unsanitary conditions.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A favorite restaurant getting shut down by the health department for having unsanitary conditions is not a good thing because it means that the food being served there was not up to standard and posed a health risk to customers.

premise: The waiter spilled coffee on my $1000 suit.
hypothesis: The waiter's carelessness made me feel an overbearing sense of joy when he spilled coffee on my $1000 suit
label: Contradiction
explanation: The suit is a valuable item and so getting coffee spilled on it would cause one to feel upset and not joyous.

premise: In puebla, the sauce was light and watery.
hypothesis: In puebla, the sauce was like liquid tar

explanation: Tar is a thick, black substance, whereas water is thin and clear, so the sauce being like liquid tar would indicate it is thick, not thin and watery.

premise: Ramesh's parents surely felt that he was an intelligent boy.
hypothesis: Ramesh's parents felt that he was a bright boy.

premise: You want to pay for the entire thing yourself?
hypothesis: You want to go halves?

premise: Emptying  with awe was Hiawatha.

premise: I get aggravated with people who don't understand personal space.

premise: I fell asleep during my date last night.

premise: For the third time in two weeks someone at work has stolen my lunch and no one will admit it.

premise: I was so irritated on the flight when the kid kept kicking the back of my chair.

label: Contradiction

premise: The party was so good till she left and now it is hell.

premise: The plant grew slowly

premise: You couldn't order right in a dennys immediately and without thinking .

premise: When Kade was a star quarterback, he was not very impressive and less exciting than the average person.

premise: She was  Blonde and blue eyed and delicate

premise: Unfortunately, their ideas about your past life are eerily accurate.

premise: They all agree the books are good reads, but they are too realistic.

premise: I was cut off in traffic the other day and it caused me to spill my coffee.

label: Contradiction

premise: My little brother dumped a glass of water on me while I was sleeping just because we are in a prank war
hypothesis: Its totally cute how my monster of a brother would dump a glass of water on me while I am sleeping just because we are in a prank war
label: Contradiction
explanation: The act of dumping a glass of water on someone while they are sleeping is not cute or funny, but instead can be dangerous as it can lead to the person being woken up by the cold water and consequently being unable to get back to sleep.

premise: It's so gross that my downstairs neighbors always lets their dog poop in the middle of the street.

premise: I am still in shock after my house caught on fire.
hypothesis: My house was engulfed in flames, so that was something that really cheered me up.
label: Contradiction

premise: I robbed a charity organization last week.

premise: Your suspicion is accurate.

premise: I feel the book really captured her attention.

premise: This was unclearly conveyed in the first try.

premise: She starts her lectures by telling a bunch of jokes.

explanation: To seal something means to close it off or make it final, while to start something means to begin it.

premise: I can't get my money under control.
hypothesis: I'm not angry at all over how I can't seem to get my money situation under control.

premise: I always eat all of the ice cream before my kids have any

label: Contradiction

premise: But then, she shouldn't hurry in getting to the point, either.
hypothesis: But then, she shouldn't beat about the bush, either.

premise: From the moment he'd crawled out of bed earlier that morning he knew the day was going to take an unexpected turn.
hypothesis: From the moment he'd crawled out of bed earlier that morning he knew the day was going to throw a curve ball.

premise: I think I may have gotten my coworker in trouble by accidentally telling our boss that he was at the waterpark last week when he called in sick.

explanation: A good coworker would not want to get their colleague in trouble and would feel guilty and absolutely no pride if they did so, even if it was by accident .

premise: The entire police department in Ashland is dirty.

label: Entailment
explanation: Three-week-old gym socks are very dirty, and so the simile is suggesting that the police department is just as dirty.

premise: Far above him things moved in the heavens.
hypothesis: Far above him  swam  the heavens ,
label: Entailment
explanation: Here swam is used to  mean  moved .

premise: Jealous of the applause they withheld from him.
hypothesis: Jealous of the applause they  gave  him ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone is jealous of the applause that is being given to someone else, it means they are envious of the attention and praise that the other person is receiving, whereas, if someone is jealous of the applause that is being withheld from someone else, it means they are angry and resentful because the other person is not receiving the recognition that they deserve.

premise: It's futile to pull against the wall with all her strength.
hypothesis: She pressed against the wall with all her strength.
label: Contradiction

premise: I have no idea how he did it, but he sure solved the very challenging problem decisively.
hypothesis: I have no idea how he did it, but he sure cut the gordian knot.“

explanation: To cut the Gordian knot means to solve a very challenging problem decisively, which is what he did in this sentence.

premise: Provide the best education possible for our children because we are putting money into it.

premise: Which horse are you surrendering on.

premise: I am so tired of having to compete for my own boyfriend's attention.

label: Contradiction
explanation: It can be tiring when someone has to compete for their partner's attention, because it shows that they are not valued highly and are not prioritized in the relationship so its unlely to feel fantastic about it.

explanation: The idiom "that makes two of us" means the same is true for me, so Richard is saying that he feels the same way.

premise: I was looking forward to a picnic on Sunday but I'm gutted it will be raining.
hypothesis: I was looking forward to a fun day outside but the forecast of lovely rain completely made my picnic plans a hit

explanation: Diseppeared from radad is similar to vanishing into thin air, which means that someone suddenly disappears and cannot be found.

hypothesis: She said, you have to swipe your card to get into any public place, so if you lose that you're up shit creek.

explanation: It is very frustrating when someone continues to call you even after you have taken measures to stop them and so it is natural to feel annoyed.

hypothesis: For all his words he did not feel any better, he felt like a burrow-baby in the jaws of a whiptail.

premise: I felt terrible when I broke our television a few weeks ago
hypothesis: I felt like the best person ever when I accidentally broke our television a few weeks ago

explanation: Accidentally breaking something is not a praiseworthy act and so feeling like the best person ever born when one does such a thing is highly unrealistic and sarcastic.

premise: I stepped in gum someone spit on the side walk

premise: Did this man not have any limits or restrictions?

explanation: To know no bounds means to be without limit or restriction, and in this context the man is without any limits or restrictions.

premise: His words cut through the air crisply.
hypothesis: The words cut through the air like a hot iron sharpening skirt pleats.
label: Entailment
explanation: A hot iron is used to sharpen pleats in skirts in a crisp manner, so the simile here implies that  her words cuts through the fabric crisply.

premise: My wife is going to divorce me.

label: Contradiction
explanation: Owing a lot of money can lead to a separation or divorce and so someone being excited about that prospect is not at all logical.

premise: Her heart was beating slowly and steadily inside her ribs.
hypothesis: Her heart fluttered in her ribs like a butterflys wings .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A butterfly's wings flutter rapidly, so comparing her heart to butterfly wings implies her heart was beating weakly and quickly, not slowly and steadily.

premise: I feel so upset when other people tell such horrible lies about other people.
hypothesis: I just love it when people lie about other people because it makes me so happy
label: Contradiction
explanation: Lying about other people is not a good virtue and it should not make anyone feel happy but instead feel bad.

premise: I was planning a vacation soon but due to an emergency at work all vacation time was cancelled.
hypothesis: The fact that my emergency at work cancelled all my vacation time makes me feel terrible

explanation: When people have been looking forward to a vacation and have made all the necessary arrangements but then have to cancel due to an emergency at work, they often feel upset and terrible.

premise: Every time I meet a girl on Tinder and she starts to like me things go bad.
hypothesis: The reason why I think online dating is a waste of time is because every time I meet a girl on Tinder she starts to like me and then everything goes bad

explanation: Online dating often leads to people meeting each other in person and if things always go bad when this happens then it is likely that someone would think online dating is a waste of time.

premise: The game is boring
hypothesis: The game is as fun as a grey park
label: Entailment
explanation: A grey park is a dull, uninteresting place - in other words, it is boring.

premise: I am working from home and do not see other people.
hypothesis: I feel like I am in such good company because I am working from home today.

explanation: Working from home implies that the person is working alone and so they are not in good company.

premise: All they wanted were his - of course!.
hypothesis: All they wanted were his - not on your life!

premise: Still waters shaking in the wind
hypothesis: Still waters pool in the wind.
label: Entailment
explanation: Still waters pool in the wind means that the water is slowly shaking in the wind.

premise: I was frightened when I opened my patio door and saw a big rat.
hypothesis: When I opened my patio door and saw a big rat, I was excited out of my mind

label: Contradiction

premise: The headline read, local celebrities receiving a lot of intense criticism or judgment.
hypothesis: The headline read, local celebrities under fire.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be under fire means to be subject to intense criticism or judgment, which is what the headline is stating.

premise: When my ex boyfriend of over 4 years suddenly just up and left me for another woman I didnt know what to do with myself.
hypothesis: After my ex-boyfriend of over 4 years left me cruelly for another woman, I felt really great
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone is left by their partner after being in a relationship for a long time, it is natural to feel hurt, angry and upset and so feeling great is definitely not an appropriate response.

premise: My laptop broke and I lost all the information on it.
hypothesis: The fact that my laptop broke and I lost all the information on it makes me high spirited and cheerful.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing all the information on a laptop is definitely not a good thing and so someone being high spirited and cheerful about it cannot be justified.

premise: My face was so red when I tried to spin my ball while bowling and ended up just throwing it.

premise: People offering her the opportunity of a lifetime to become involved in something at its beginning of a great business opportunity.
hypothesis: People offering her the opportunity of a lifetime to get in on the ground floor of a great business opportunity.
label: Entailment
explanation: To get in on the ground floor means to become involved in something at its beginning, which is what is happening in this sentence.

premise: This has not been a good year for us and we must be prepared to make do with what we have and not spend extravagantly.
hypothesis: This has not been a good year for us and we must be prepared to cut our coat according to our cloth.

premise: Come on, you lazy bones, get out of bed!
hypothesis: Come on, you lazy bones, show a leg !
label: Entailment
explanation: To show a leg means to get out of bed, which is what the speaker wants the lazy bones to do.

premise: I get so ticked off when I see people leave their grocery carts in the middle of the parking lot.
hypothesis: I love it when I see people leaving their grocery carts in the middle of the parking lot
label: Contradiction
explanation: People who leave their grocery carts in the middle of the parking lot are being inconsiderate and creating a mess, so seeing them do that does not evoke feelings of love but rather annoyance.

premise: Their desire was very intense and it was palpable.

label: Entailment
explanation: When a person is said to be burning with desire, it means that their desire is very intense.

premise: We will, gentlemen, succeed or fail together on this, because we are too closely linked to do anything else.

label: Entailment

label: Contradiction

premise: I ordered food almost two hours ago and it's still not here ugh!

premise: I have been diagnosed with psoriatic arthritis and the pain is horrible.

premise: I broke my coffee maker today and I'm so mad because I can't make coffee.

hypothesis: It opened its mouth and screamed, revealing rows of tiny sharp teeth and clawing at jason's muzzle as jason tried to get a grip with his own teeth.

premise: The knocking on the door was really persuasive and persistent.

premise: He insisted and took the advice of not  ignoring my objections .

explanation: A dead slug would not be working at all because it is dead, hence the simile is saying that he did not work hard.

explanation: It is often very frightening to see two groups of people fighting as it can often get out of control and be dangerous.
