hypothesis: I was totally pleased when my dad borrowed my car and got into an accident, which then made my insurance rate increase
label: Contradiction
explanation: No one would be pleased when their dad borrows their car and gets into an accident because it would mean that the person would have to pay more money for insurance and also have to deal with the hassle of repairing the car.

premise: David is a despicable person for what he did to Shelia.
hypothesis: David is a worm for what he did to Shelia.
label: Entailment
explanation: A worm is a small, slimy creature that is often seen as being weak and insignificant, so, here, David is being compared to a worm because of his actions.

premise: He had a slim phone in his pocket, a secure digital unit.
hypothesis: There was a phone in his pocket, a secure digital unit like a cigarette lighter.
label: Entailment
explanation: A cigarette lighter is a small and slim object, so the phone must be small and slim as well.

premise: What about the idea that helping strangers should be your priority?
hypothesis: What about the idea that charity begins at home?
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom charity begins at home means that one should help family and close friends before helping others, but the contradiction is that helping strangers should be your priority.

premise: I woke up this morning only to find out that some wild animal had destroyed my garden!
hypothesis: I woke up this morning to find that some animal had destroyed my garden which is a total blessing
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not at all a blessing to find that an animal has destroyed your garden because it would have taken a lot of time and effort to make it look nice in the first place.

premise: If I could just stay away from engaging in the situation for a couple of hours and try to change it or assert control over it, I may just have a decent enough time to get through it.
hypothesis: If I could just go with the flow for a couple of hours, I may just have a decent enough time to get through it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go with the flow is to nonchalantly engage in a situation, but the speaker wants to stay away from engaging the situation and wants to assert control.

premise: MY neighbors are always leaving trash on our stairwell.
hypothesis: I am elated about the fact that my neighbors never put their trash in the trash can and it piles up on our stairwell.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Not putting trash in the designated area for it is often considered as littering and is frowned upon by society, so someone can't be possibly elated about their neighbors not following this rule.

premise: Are you going to ask your question, or are you going to suddenly stop talking about your love affair with your backside?
hypothesis: Are you going to ask your question, or are you going to go on and on about your love affair with your backside?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go on and on means to continue or speak for a tedious or exasperating length of time, but the sentence describes the person stopping suddenly.

premise: I accidentally told my best friend's secret to a mutual friend
hypothesis: I feel like such a loyal friend for accidentally telling my best friend's secret to a mutual friend
label: Contradiction
explanation: A loyal friend would not accidentally tell their best friend's secret to a mutual friend and instead would be more careful about it.

premise: This operation is transparent
hypothesis: This operation is as transparent as tinted glass
label: Contradiction
explanation: Tinted glass is not transparent because it has a color, so it blocks light.

premise: I bit into an apple and found a worm and it was so gross.
hypothesis: I never felt better than when I discovered a worm inside the apple I was eating.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Apples are a healthy and often eaten food, so finding a worm inside it would make anyone feel disgusted and sick instead of better.

premise: My family buys my adult sister things all the time but can't really help me out when I need it.
hypothesis: I just love it that that my family buys my adult sister things all the time but can't really help me out when I need it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Adult siblings often don't need help from their family members as much as the younger siblings do and so the fact that the family can't really help the young one out when they need it implies that they are biased.

premise: But I don't want to be fighting immediately after eating a lot, so I might as well keep my muscles warm.
hypothesis: But I don't want to be fighting on a full stomach, so I might as well keep my muscles warm.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be on a full stomach means to have just eaten to the point of being full, and in this context the person does not want to fight immediately after eating.

premise: She might not take any action or responsibility once she knew what a crappy job her son was doing of raising her granddaughter.
hypothesis: She might step up to the plate once she knew what a crappy job her son was doing of raising her granddaughter.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To step up to the plate means to take action in response to an opportunity or crisis, but in this context she is not taking any action.

premise: I was supposed to be off work 3 hours ago but I'm still here.
hypothesis: I love how my boss expects me to still be here at the office 3 hours after my shift was supposed to end.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is unreasonable for someone's boss to expect them to stay at the office after their shift has ended and so the boss is being unfair.

premise: The few staff who are still with us are growing tired of the empty promises of something better in the future, while having to endure longer hours with less pay.
hypothesis: The few staff who are still with us are growing tired of the jam tomorrow discourse, while having to endure longer hours with less pay.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom jam tomorrow means an empty promise of something that will never arrive, and in this context the staff are growing tired of those kinds of promises.

premise: I had to send my food back at the restaurant today because it was so bad.
hypothesis: I was so disappointed with the food I received at the restaurant that I had to send it back
label: Entailment
explanation: The food not meeting someone's expectations is often very disappointing and can result in the person sending the food back.

premise: The sound of his own blood sounded soothing and calming.
hypothesis: The sound of his own blood sounds like scraping metal against a chalkboard.
label: Contradiction
explanation: most people find the sound of scraping metal against a chalkboard to be incredibly annoying and unpleasant.

premise: I was thinking about my leftover Chinese food, came home and someone had eaten it
hypothesis: When I got home, I found that my Chinese food was missing and it made me really grateful that someone ate it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting home to find that your food is missing would usually make someone angry and not grateful because they would think that someone stole it.

premise: I'm going to urinate.
hypothesis: I'm going to take a leak.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take a leak means to urinate.

premise: I went to a party at a friends house and I spilled a drink on the floor.
hypothesis: I felt extremely competent when I accidentally spilled my drink on the floor at my friend's party
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spilling drinks is often considered to be clumsy and embarrassing, and so someone feeling competent after doing it would be unrealistic.

premise: I heard the in-flight entertainment is amazing and wonderful.
hypothesis: I heard the in-flight entertainment is out of this world.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be out of this world means to be extraordinary, and in this sentence the in-flight entertainment is said to be amazing and wonderful.

premise: The library grew back pretty
hypothesis: The library grew back like a persistent garden.
label: Entailment
explanation: A persistent garden is one that is always growing and thriving, regardless of the conditions.

premise: There was something about Callum's behaviour that she didn't like, something in his grin that made her want to stay and confront him.
hypothesis: There was something about callums behaviour that she didn't like, something in his grin that made her want to run a mile.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run a mile means to avoid something in any way possible, but the context describes wanting to stay and confront him.

premise: The smoke rising from the pyrotechnics was so thick it was difficult to see.
hypothesis: Smoke rising from erupting pyrotechnics was like a london fog.
label: Entailment
explanation: A london fog is a thick fog that obscures vision.

premise: The businessman gave millions of dollars away.
hypothesis: The businessman kited millions of dollars.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Kiting is a type of fraud where someone uses a check or draft that has been drawn on insufficient funds in order to purchase something, so, the businessman who gave millions of dollars away would be the opposite of kiting.

premise: I stayed in a house with a rat problem for a while, it was not fun.
hypothesis: I would love to stay in a house again that had a rat problem because it was not only amazing but also super enjoyable
label: Contradiction
explanation: A rat problem in a house is never amazing and can cause a lot of diseases and damage, so it is not enjoyable at all.

premise: She might look ruthless to the human eye, Sean could tell that she was full of shame for being stern with such a dishonest man.
hypothesis: She might look ruthless to the human eye, but sean could tell she was full of shame at being so stern with a man like a persistent puppy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A puppy is typically thought of as being cute, innocent, and honest, while a dishonest man is two-faced and not to be trusted.

premise: Does anyone want to split the cost individually?
hypothesis: Anyone want to go halves?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go halves means to share the cost evenly between two people, but this sentence asks if anyone wants to split the cost individually.

premise: When I was a kid I really wanted to go to disney but my parents couldn't afford it so we never had the chance to go
hypothesis: It's great that my parents saved me from the excitement of going to Disney as a kid by telling me we couldn't afford it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would want to go to an amusement park and have fun and so not being able to go because of financial constraints is not a great thing.

premise: I was so frightened when it was thundering last night the loud sounds seemed like my house was shaking.
hypothesis: I was feel deep sense of calm when it was thundering last night because the loud sounds made it seem like my house was shaking.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Thundering can be a very loud and frightening sound, so feeling calm because of it is quite contradictory.

premise: She sought information from the witnesses.
hypothesis: She pressed the witnesses for information.
label: Entailment
explanation: Pressing for information means seeking information from someone.

premise: Then he collided into something hard and sharp
hypothesis: Then he collided into something like a marshmallow pond.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A marshmallow pond is soft and fluffy since its filled with marshmallow candy, whereas something hard and sharp would be the opposite.

premise: The bad review made him feel miserable and thus diminished his confidence.
hypothesis: The bad review of his work deflated his self-confidence.
label: Entailment
explanation: Deflated means to reduce in size or importance, so in this case, the bad review made him feel small and unimportant.

premise: The resemblance was uncanny .
hypothesis: The resemblance was like a really good caricature .
label: Entailment
explanation: A caricature is an exaggerated likeness, so the implication is that the resemblance was so close that it was almost like looking at the actual person.

premise: By this time the last batteries in their flashlight are about to start working again and come back to life.
hypothesis: By this time the last batteries in their flashlight are about to give up the ghost.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To give up the ghost means to stop working, but in this sentence the batteries are about to start working again.

premise: I tried following a recipe for vegan cookies and they turned out horribly.
hypothesis: I was so excited to try out this vegan cookie recipe, but they turned out to be a total disaster
label: Entailment
explanation: When something that is anticipated to be good turns out to be bad it is often disappointing and this was the case for the vegan cookies.

premise: It was so difficult to live in a camp that it made him tired.
hypothesis: Life in the camp drained him.
label: Entailment
explanation: Living in the camp was so difficult that it made him tired.

premise: Hitler skittered off slowly
hypothesis: Hitler skittered off like a dog with its tail between its legs.
label: Entailment
explanation: A dog with its tail between its legs is scared, so this simile is saying that Hitler was scared and skittered off slowly.

premise: I am terrified that someone got shot near my house the other day.
hypothesis: I am scared that somebody was just shot near my house and that it could happen to me too
label: Entailment
explanation: People often get scared when they hear about other people getting shot because it makes them feel like it could happen to them too and they could be the next victim.

premise: he is a coward
hypothesis: He is as brave as a cow
label: Entailment
explanation: Cows are not known to be brave animals, so the simile is indicating that the person is not brave.

premise: I fed my dog a new dog food and he puked ALL over my house!
hypothesis: Love how I gave my dog a new dog food and he projectile vomited all over my house!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dogs throwing up after eating can be a common occurrence and is often disgusting, so someone loving it is definitely not warranted.

premise: I got an older car for my 16th birthday, but my best friend got a BRAND new BMW!
hypothesis: Even though I got an older car for my 16th birthday, I feel really envious of my best friend who got a BRAND new BMW!
label: Entailment
explanation: It's human nature to feel envious when someone you know gets something that is much nicer than what you have, especially if it's something that you really wanted.

premise: I had my hopes up to win a sweet contract I bid on but they chose someone else for the project.
hypothesis: I was really looking forward to winning the sweet contract I bid on, but was delighted to see that the geniuses chose someone else
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone bids on a contract and does not win it, they are usually disappointed instead of delighted because they put in a lot of effort into preparing for it.

premise: I am so upset, my phone was on top of my car and it fell off and shattered.
hypothesis: My phone, that was on top of my car, suddenly fell off and shattered, so that's my best day ever.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dropping or losing a phone is usually a very traumatic experience for most people because it means they have to spend more money to repair it or get a new one and hence can make them feel upset or like they have had the worst day ever.

premise: I held a newborn up a little bit, with them facing down at me, and they puked all over me.
hypothesis: The smell of baby vomit is one of the best smells I have ever encountered
label: Contradiction
explanation: Baby vomit is not a pleasant smell and often smells very acidic which can be unpleasant for people.

premise: His stomach felt hollow
hypothesis: His stomach felt like a well.
label: Entailment
explanation: A well is a hollow or empty space.

premise: For the 3rd month in a row I have received and incorrect cell phone bill!
hypothesis: I love that I have to call customer service for the 3rd month in a row to get my cell phone bill fixed because it's always wrong!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Receiving a cell phone bill that is incorrect for the third time in a row is really frustrating and indicative of poor customer service and so someone who loves it in it is not reasonable.

premise: If you want fresh food, just ignore your gut feeling and you will find villagers happy to sell or trade what they have.
hypothesis: If you want fresh food, just follow your noses and you will find villagers happy to sell or trade what they have.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To follow your nose means to trust one's instinct, but in this sentence you would need to ignore your gut feeling to find fresh food.

premise: My kids spilled juice on my brand new white carpet.
hypothesis: I am so pleased that my kids spilled juice on my brand new white carpet, I thought it needed a pattern.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spilling juice on a white carpet is not a pleasing thing because it will leave a stain and is difficult to clean.

premise: I bite back, not enough to do damage but definitely enough to let him know that I am serious about what I am saying.
hypothesis: I bite back, not hard enough to do damage but definitely hard enough to let him know that I mean business.
label: Entailment
explanation: To mean business is to be serious about what one is promising or proposing to do, and the speaker is indicating that they let people know that they are serious by biting back.

premise: I ate all my kids cookies and blamed it on the dog.
hypothesis: I ate all my kids cookies and felt totally proud about the fact that I blamed it on the dog.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Blaming someone else for something you have done wrong is never a good thing and so feeling no guilt after doing something terrible like eating all your kids cookies is very unlikely.

premise: A friend let me borrow some of his old headphones and now I have lost them.
hypothesis: A friend let me borrow his old headphones and now I feel thrilled that I lost them
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing something that does not belong to you is not a responsible thing to do and hence the person cannot feel thrilled about it.

premise: I haven't heard from my friend in 3 days.
hypothesis: I am really scared that my friend is in trouble because I have not heard from her in 3 days
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often worrisome when somebody does not hear from their friend for an extended period of time as it might mean that the person is in danger or has gotten into some sort of trouble.

premise: I had a bad day and tried calling two different people and couldn't get anyone
hypothesis: I feel so alone because I had a terrible day and no one wanted to pick up my call
label: Entailment
explanation: When people have a bad day, they often want to talk to someone about it but if they can't get ahold of anyone it can make them feel isolated and alone.

premise: False and insincere tears, they were soon blinked back when they didn't win any softening from her.
hypothesis: Crocodile tears, since they were soon blinked back when they didn't win any softening from her.
label: Entailment
explanation: Crocodile tears are a false and insincere display of sadness, and in this sentence they were quickly blinked back when they didn't win any softening from her.

premise: After decades of drought the Western United States is finally declared habitable.
hypothesis: After decades of drought the Western United states is declared a wasteland.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A wasteland is an area that is uninhabitable, so it cannot be declared habitable.

premise: My house flooded with all the rain!
hypothesis: I was pleased to see that my house got filled with water because of the crazy rainstorm!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Flooding caused by rainstorms is often a huge inconvenience and can damage property so receiving water in one's house because of it is not something to be pleased about.

premise: I've spent the last year of my life feeling secure, trusted and approved.
hypothesis: I've spent the last year of my life under a cloud.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be under a cloud means to be viewed with suspicion, distrust or disapproval, but this context describes the opposite feeling of being secure, trusted and approved.

premise: My bank just locked me out of my account so now I have no way to get access to my money.
hypothesis: I am so angry that my bank just locked me out of my account and now I have no way to get access to my money
label: Entailment
explanation: Being locked out of a bank account is very frustrating because it prevents people from being able to access their own money.

premise: I felt let down by my girlfriend when she decided to move some money out of our joint account without telling me.
hypothesis: I felt really loved when my girlfriend moved some money out of our joint account without telling me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Taking money out of a joint account without telling the other person is not a honest or lovely thing to do and so the speaker was not happy about it.

premise: My supervisor took all the credit for a new client I brought in without even recognizing that I was involved.
hypothesis: My supervisor is such a saint for taking all the credit for a new client I brought in without even mentioning my involvement
label: Contradiction
explanation: A supervisor taking credit for a new client that an employee brought in is unfair and shows that the supervisor is not a saint but rather ignorant and inconsiderate.

premise: The overhead light buzzed irritatingly, at the edge of hearing.
hypothesis: The overhead light buzzed at the edge of hearing, like a fly.
label: Entailment
explanation: A fly buzzes irritatingly and can be hard to swat, similarly the light was buzzing at a frequency that was hard to ignore.

premise: For now, it stretched out before me for a short finite distance.
hypothesis: But for now it stretched out before me like a sky full of stars
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sky full of stars appears to be infinite to the human observer due to the number of starts in the universe.

premise: It was a slow fire that burned between them.
hypothesis: It lit the fire between them like a match ignites timber.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A match ignites timber quickly, so saying it lit the fire between them like a match ignites timber means it was a quick fire.

premise: The fans become calm and rational.
hypothesis: The fans go bananas.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go bananas means to become irrational or crazy, but the fans in this sentence become calm and rational instead.

premise: I accidentally stepped in dog feces today.
hypothesis: I stepped in some dog feces today and it made me feel disgusted
label: Entailment
explanation: Stepping in dog feces is an accident that often happens but it is a very disgusting thing to do and often leaves people feeling sick to their stomach.

premise: The rich man was a very kind-hearted person.
hypothesis: The rich man had a cold heart.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A cold heart is often seen as being insensitive or unemotional, while a kind-hearted person is someone who is caring and compassionate.

premise: His words were muddled and unclear.
hypothesis: The words cut through the air like a hot iron sharpening skirt pleats.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hot iron is used to sharpen pleats in skirts in a crisp manner, so the simile here implies that  her words cuts through the fabric crisply instead of in a muddled and unclear way.

premise: This problem allows for more than one solution to fix it.
hypothesis: This problem admits of no solution.
label: Contradiction
explanation: One statement says there is no solution while other statement says that the problem allows for more than one solution to fix it.

premise: When I came back from my vacation, I was horrified when I found that there is a rat in my garden.
hypothesis: When I came back from my vacation, I was traumatized when I found that there is a rat in my garden
label: Entailment
explanation: coming back from a vacation to find a rat in the garden is pretty traumatizing because it means that the rat has been there for a while and it could have done some damage.

premise: The value of a dollar has reduced so much now by inflation.
hypothesis: The dollar has been dragged by inflation.
label: Entailment
explanation: The value of a dollar has decreased because of inflation.

premise: If you still feel the same way about him when the time comes to sign the lease, then go ahead with it and take the risk.
hypothesis: If you still feel the same away about him when the time comes to sign the lease, then take the plunge.”
label: Entailment
explanation: To take the plunge means to commit oneself to a course of action that is momentous or challenging, which is what she is suggesting to do by go ahead with it and taking the risk.

premise: It told them that they really knew what they were dealing with and it was best to get involved with it.
hypothesis: It told them that they truly had no idea what they were dealing with and it was best to leave well alone.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To leave well alone means to stay away from something so as to avoid unintentionally causing problems, but in this context it told them to get involved.

premise: I dislike and have no respect for Jacqueline and Reese for the way they helped Alix, encouraged her through her schooling and as a bride-to-be.
hypothesis: I think the world of jacqueline and reese for the way they helped alix, helped and encouraged her through her schooling and as a bride-to-be.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To think the world of someone is to greatly admire and respect them, but in this context the speaker dislikes and has no respect for them.

premise: This one was too healthy to die in the middle of the night, he might need a bit of help to kick the bucket.
hypothesis: This one was too healthy to pop his clogs in the middle of the night, he might need a bit of help to shuffle off this mortal coil.
label: Entailment
explanation: To shuffle off this mortal coil means to die, and in this context the person is too healthy to die without help.

premise: I went to a local restaurant ,but the gloves that they wore touch everything including my food.
hypothesis: I feel totally violated that the gloves that the restaurant staff wore touched my food
label: Entailment
explanation: Wearing gloves is a way to protect food from contamination but if the gloves are touching everything including the food that people are going to eat, it can make them feel violated because they are not sure if the food is clean.

premise: He was terrified
hypothesis: He was like a rabbit staring into the headlights of an approaching car;
label: Entailment
explanation: A rabbit staring into the headlights of an oncoming car is an image of terror, as the rabbit is about to be run over.

premise: Are you not asking to be punished or harmed?
hypothesis: Are you cruising for a bruising?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be cruising for a bruising is to be asking for trouble, so the contradiction is asking if they are not asking to be punished.

premise: My brother wouldn't leave me alone and I think I'm going to punch him!
hypothesis: My wonderful brother wouldn't stop following me around and I was this close to gifting him with a punch.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not want someone to follow them around and so the brother following around constantly is not wonderful but rather annoying.

premise: His skin was rough, and he had a round face with golden curly hair.
hypothesis: His skin felt like a doves feathers and his little face was round, set by a golden crown of curls.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dove feathers are soft, so if his skin felt like them, it would also be soft, not rough.

premise: It was debatable whether or not Paul was nice.
hypothesis: Paul was nice, no two ways about it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To have no two ways about it means that there is no choice or alternative interpretation, but this context suggests that there is another interpretation where Paul might not be nice.

premise: My vision is obscured and not clear
hypothesis: My vision is as clear as stained glass
label: Entailment
explanation: A stained glass window is not transparent, so you cannot see through it clearly.

premise: He could not progress or find success in any area of his life.
hypothesis: He could go places.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go places means to progress or find success in some area of one's life, but this sentence states that he could not do so.

premise: What-the-hell was right: looming behind them was a boxy building tall as a church steeple looking unadorned
hypothesis: What-the-hell was right: looming behind them was a boxy building tall as a church steeple, resembling a recycling bin.
label: Entailment
explanation: A recycling bin is a plain, functional object, whereas a church steeple is ornate and decorative.

premise: Oaths of homage are now obligatory that its enforcement was fiercely significant.
hypothesis: Oaths of homage fiercely won.
label: Entailment
explanation: The Oath of Homage is a pledge of allegiance to a lord in the feudal system and here in this context it remained an obligatory part.

premise: The place was packed and the tobacco smoke was thick.
hypothesis: The place was packed and the tobacco smoke was like a london fog.
label: Entailment
explanation: A London fog is a thick fog , so the simile is saying that the smoke was thick.

premise: I had been looking a pictures of car crashes and now I am afraid to drive anywhere.
hypothesis: I had been looking at pictures of car crashes and now I am confident to drive anywhere
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing pictures of car crashes can often lead to fear and a lack of confidence when driving, so someone who says that they are now confident to drive anywhere is being sarcastic.

premise: I've been hearing some strange noises around the house at night.
hypothesis: I am freaked out about the weird noises I keep hearing around the house at night.
label: Entailment
explanation: It is normal to be freaked out when hearing strange noises around the house because it could be a sign of an intruder or something else that is potentially dangerous.

premise: I felt pretty down when I found out that I was losing my job.
hypothesis: I felt terrible when I found out that I was going to lose my job
label: Entailment
explanation: Losing a job is often a very traumatic experience and can result in feeling down or terrible.

premise: Let puritans and pessimists damn , disapprove or dismiss these strong desires ; that is their loss .
hypothesis: Let puritans and pessimists damn , disapprove or dismiss these appetites ; that is their loss .
label: Entailment
explanation: Here, ``appetites'' are used to mean the strong desires.

premise: My husband had to cancel a vacation for next month because his other night manager is terrible and they cant afford to let him go.
hypothesis: My husband had to cancel our vacation ext month because his other night manager is such a fantastic boss that they can't afford to let him go.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cancelling a vacation because of work shows that the husband's boss is not very understanding or considerate and hence is not a good boss.

premise: I bet I am red.
hypothesis: I bet I am like a cherry.
label: Entailment
explanation: A cherry is a red fruit, so the simile is saying that the person is red, likely meaning they are flushed or embarrassed.

premise: My boss embarrassed me infront of the investors.
hypothesis: I was excited when my boss embarrassed me infront of the investors
label: Contradiction
explanation: The boss displaying poor judgement in front of the investors is not something to feel excited for because it could lead to a negative evaluation of the company and loss of jobs.

premise: It was neither beautiful nor violent
hypothesis: It was like a cold sunset filled with the furious motion of an icy hell.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sunset is generally considered to be a beautiful scene, and an icy hell is a violent place, so saying it was like a cold sunset filled with the furious motion of an icy hell implies that it was both beautiful and violent.

premise: With global warming and political turmoil I sometimes worry about the future and what it could hold for the future generations.
hypothesis: I worry about the future and whether or not it'll be a good one because of global warming and political turmoil
label: Entailment
explanation: Global warming and political turmoil are two big problems that often make people worry about the future and what it will be like for future generations.

premise: She let anyone treat her very badly and they did and she didn't react, not even a little.
hypothesis: She let anyone walk all over her and they did and she didn't react, not even a little.
label: Entailment
explanation: To walk all over someone means to treat them very badly, and in this context she lets people treat her badly and doesn't react at all.

premise: I could not believe that my mom gave my sister her favorite necklace it is not fair!
hypothesis: I took it in stride when my mom gave my sister her favorite necklace and not me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is natural for siblings to feel upset when one gets a gift and the other does not, so expecting someone to take it in stride when they are not favored is unreasonable.

premise: His skin was very white and he had that hideous disease of no hair-no eyebrows and no eyelashes, and none on a head that was dull.
hypothesis: His skin was very white and he had that hideous disease of no hair-no eyebrows and no eyelashes, and none on a head that was like a billiard ball.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A billiard ball is shiny, so saying someone's head is like a billiard ball would imply that it is shiny, not dull.

premise: This story, however, is about a god who is useless.
hypothesis: This tale, however, speaks of a god who's as incompetent as a wagon without wheels.
label: Entailment
explanation: A wagon without wheels is completely useless and cannot perform its intended function.

premise: The sandwich was very dry
hypothesis: The sandwich was as dry as a crab at the bottom of the sea
label: Contradiction
explanation: A crab at the bottom of the sea is surrounded with water, making it very moist.

premise: My wifi is not working properly
hypothesis: I'm really happy because my wifi is not working and I can't get any work done
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people need wifi to be able to work and not having it working would frustrate them instead of making them happy because it hinders their productivity.

premise: The chicken pasta was already delivered, ate, and the check was paid.
hypothesis: The chicken pasta is waiting for his check.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To wait for something means to remain in expectation, while to have already received and eaten something would mean that the person is no longer waiting for it.

premise: I wouldn't have believed myself capable of attracting anyone, except for such a man.
hypothesis: I wouldn't have believed myself capable of attracting anyone, let alone such a man.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The phrase let alone is used to emphasize that if other more significant or pressing things are not possible  a lesser thing certainly is not or cannot either but in this context, the speaker is emphasizing that attracting anyone would not have been possible, except attracting a man which is contradictory.

premise: My mother in law does not know how to mind her business.
hypothesis: My lovely mother in law is always butting into my personal life and it makes me so happy
label: Contradiction
explanation: Interference from a mother in law in someone's personal life is often unwelcome and considered to be an intrusion, so someone saying that it makes them feel happy is sarcastic.

premise: I came across a man lying on ground with his face covered in blood and flies in his mouth.
hypothesis: I was disgusted to see a man lying on the ground with his face covered in blood and flies crawling all over his mouth
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel disgusted when seeing someone in such a condition because it is unsanitary and very unhealthy.

premise: It deceived from truth alone , the truth we live.
hypothesis: It appeared from truth alone , the truth we live.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The truth that we live is the truth that is based on our personal experiences, while if it deceiced then it is based on lies or deception.

premise: I felt scared about what I might not see each time we turned a corner.
hypothesis: I felt scared about what I might lay eyes on each time we turned a corner.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To lay eyes on something is to see it, but in this context she was scared of what she might not see.

premise: For a moment, his eyes danced and I saw a slow fade to black.
hypothesis: His eyes danced for a moment and I caught something like a lighter sparking right before it jumps to full flame.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lighter sparking right before it jumps to full flame is sudden and bright, whereas a slow fade to black is gradual and dark.

premise: I am still in shock after my house caught on fire.
hypothesis: I am thrilled after my house was engulfed in flames
label: Contradiction
explanation: A house being engulfed in flames is a terrible thing to happen as it causes destruction and people are usually shocked instead of being thrilled.

premise: She canceled her job to supervise her children.
hypothesis: She had to tend to her job and her children.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To tend to something means to take care of it or give it attention, while to cancel something means to call it off or put an end to it.

premise: If I show up anywhere the good guys are planning a raid, they will kill me.
hypothesis: If I show up anywhere the white hats are planning a raid, they will kill me.
label: Entailment
explanation: White hats are known to be good guys, and if the good guys are planning a raid then it would be bad for the person in the context.

premise: My neighbor was having a party last night and wouldn't let me sleep.
hypothesis: My neighbor's party was so loud last night and I never slept so peacefully.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A party going on next door is usually a loud and disruptive event which would prevent someone from sleeping peacefully and hence the neighbor's party was not actually peaceful at all.

premise: He looked modern and civilized.
hypothesis: He looked like a prowling animal .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Prowling animals are usually wild and not domesticated, so they are not usually perceived as looking modern and civilized.

premise: She swears they would have hated me because all they ever cared about was her happiness, and with me, she is discontent.
hypothesis: She swears they would have loved me because all they ever cared about was her happiness, and with me, she is like a golden eagle who swooped around the skies for years before finding its one true mate.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A golden eagle is a very powerful bird, and is content when it has found its one true mate, implying that she would be content too if they had loved him.

premise: I could not believe that my mom gave my sister her favorite necklace it is not fair!
hypothesis: I was totally shocked that my mom gave my sister her favorite necklace and not me
label: Entailment
explanation: Parents are often expected to be fair when it comes to their children, so it was surprising and unfair to the speaker that their mother would give their sister the favorite necklace.

premise: I made me a bowl of cereal today and when I started eating I realized milk was spoiled
hypothesis: When I started eating my cereal I realized the milk was spoiled and it made me feel so excited
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spoiled milk is often sour and has an unpleasant odor, so finding out that the milk for cereal is spoiled would not make someone feel excited.

premise: The little bit of stubble on his jaw made him look tame and unappealing.
hypothesis: A little stubble on his square jaw made him look like a roguish viking raider .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A viking raider is a fierce, plundering warrior, so looking like one would imply being rugged and appealing, not tame and unappealing.

premise: The children appeared beautiful and fragile.
hypothesis: The children were roses: beautiful and forlorn.
label: Entailment
explanation: Roses are beautiful and fragile flowers similar to children.

premise: He looked primitive and primal .
hypothesis: He looked like a prowling animal .
label: Entailment
explanation: A prowling animal is one that is on the hunt, looking for its next meal much like someone primitive and primal.

premise: And there are no conditions or restrictions or obligations that must be met to that recognition.
hypothesis: And there are no strings attached to that recognition.
label: Entailment
explanation: To have no strings attached means to have no conditions or restrictions or obligations that must be met and that is the criterion for recognition in this context.

premise: Mrs. Hastings kept talking about how pretty the restaurant was, but Spencer thought it was too gloomy.
hypothesis: Mrs. hastings kept clucking about how nice the surroundings were, but spencer thought the restaurant was like a funeral home.
label: Entailment
explanation: A funeral home is a place where people go to mourn the dead, and it is usually very somber and dark and gloomy.

premise: The government seems to finally be waking up and understanding.
hypothesis: The government seems to finally be seeing the light.
label: Entailment
explanation: To see the light means to understand or come to accept something, which is what the government seems to be doing in this context.

premise: My bank ended up charging me hundreds of dollars for something I didn't do.
hypothesis: I was totally calm when I found out that my bank charged me hundreds of dollars for something I didn't do.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is natural for people to get angry or upset when they are charged hundreds of dollars for something they didn't do, so feeling calm about it is not justified.

premise: He loved me tremendously, passionately, and yet, while sober by that terrible fruit, he had harmed me.
hypothesis: He loved me tremendously, passionately, and yet, while under the influence of that terrible fruit, he had harmed me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be under the influence typically means to be intoxicated, but in this context the character is sober.

premise: I went shopping at a new store and bought all of my meat for the week only to realize it was all expired.
hypothesis: I wasted all my money at this new store only to buy expired meat products
label: Entailment
explanation: It is a waste of money to buy products that are expired and will not be able to be used so buying all of the meat for the week from a new store only to find out it was expired is a waste.

premise: I was at a party with my boyfriend, and he seemed to be ignoring me.
hypothesis: I was at a party with my boyfriend and he ignoring me there made me feel super loved
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone's boyfriend ignores them at a party, it would usually make the person feel upset and unloved instead of loved.

premise: His voice transmitted up the house.
hypothesis: His voice filled up the house.
label: Entailment
explanation: To fill up something means to occupy all of the space in it, likewise, transmit something means to send it out, over all the space.

premise: Hitler skittered off quickly
hypothesis: Hitler skittered off like a dog with its tail between its legs.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A dog with its tail between its legs is a sign of submission and fear, so saying Hitler skittered off like that indicates that he was beinng slow, not just leaving quickly.

premise: He hired the kind of people who would constantly display their emotional responses such as consternation at the slimy schemes.
hypothesis: He hired the kind of people who would not bat an eyelash at the slimy schemes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom means to not display any sort of emotional response, but the context describes people who would constantly display their emotional responses.

premise: I bought some cheap stocks hoping that they would go up in price but they didn't.
hypothesis: I was very pleased with my financial expertise when the stocks I bought for cheap didn't go up in price.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Buying stocks for cheap and then them not going up in price means that the person has no financial skills and so should not be proud of themselves.

premise: My flight got delayed and the airline would not apologize and provide altenative
hypothesis: I was immensely pleased when my flight got delayed and the airline refused to apologize and provide alternative transportation
label: Contradiction
explanation: Flight delays are never a good thing and so the airline not apologizing and not providing alternative transportation was really terrible.

premise: I felt really bad when someone twisted what I said earlier today to make it seem like I was saying something else.
hypothesis: I was so embarrassed when someone twisted my words and made it seem like I said something different than what I actually meant
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often embarrassing when someone takes what you said out of context and changes the meaning to make it seem like you said something else entirely.

premise: My neighbor neglects their dog.
hypothesis: It pleases me how my kind neighbor doesn't take care of their poor dog
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be appalled at the state of their dog being neglected by their neighbor and so someone being pleased by that situation is absurd.

premise: People that flake out like that just have no respect for anyone elses' time.
hypothesis: People that flake out like that just have excellent consideration for anyone else's time
label: Contradiction
explanation: Flaking out on plans often causes inconvenience to others and hence people that do it do not have consideration for anyone else's time.

premise: His eyes were gray
hypothesis: His eyes were like a winter's sky
label: Entailment
explanation: A winter's sky is typically gray.

premise: My friend who I had plans with for the past month cancelled on me.
hypothesis: It's awesome when my friend who I had plans with for the past month cancels on me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having plans with someone for a long time and then them cancelling on you at the last minute is not a good feeling and is often very frustrating.

premise: My friend said the project was a dream come true.
hypothesis: My friend said the project was a nightmare.
label: Contradiction
explanation: One person says the project was a nightmare, while the same also says it was a dream come true.

premise: I was mislead by a worker who wanted to undermine my work.
hypothesis: I feel like I was blessed by the worker who pretended to help me but was actually trying to sabotage my work
label: Contradiction
explanation: The worker who pretended to help was actually trying to harm the work process and so receiving help from them cannot be considered a blessing.

premise: I cooked a meal for family and it came out horribly.
hypothesis: I feel proud that the meal I cooked for my family didn't turn out well
label: Contradiction
explanation: A meal that doesn't turn out well is usually not edible and not what a family would want to eat, so the person who cooked it should not feel proud about it.

premise: I aced through the work
hypothesis: I waded through the work.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To wade through something means to struggle or slog through it, while to ace through the job means to complete it successfully.

premise: I don't know why they still bother, the costly and meaningless victory which is their only hope, will leave them kings of a mountain of fire and broken glass.
hypothesis: I don't know why they still bother, the pyrrhic victory which is their only hope, will leave them kings of a mountain of fire and broken glass.
label: Entailment
explanation: A pyrrhic victory is a victory that is not worth achieving because of the excessive toll it takes on the victor, and in this context the victory is described as being costly and meaningless.

premise: I'm on a diet but I ate burger king for lunch I feel so  ashamed I cheated.
hypothesis: I feel overjoyed that I cheated on my diet by eating at Burger King for lunch
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cheating on a diet by eating unhealthy food from Burger King would not be good for someone's health and so they would not feel overjoyed after doing that.

premise: The conversation was very dull.
hypothesis: The conversation was as juicy as a business meeting
label: Entailment
explanation: A business meeting is a formal occasion where people discuss dry, boring topics.

premise: With reserve he thus gave an answer.
hypothesis: With reserve he thus made answer.
label: Entailment
explanation: He made an answer means he gave an answer.

premise: I saw my neighbor pick his nose and then put it in his mouth.
hypothesis: I saw my lovely neighbor pick his nose and then put it in his mouth.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The act of picking one's nose and then putting it in their mouth is considered to be a very gross and unsanitary thing to do and so seeing someone do that implies that they are not classy at all.

premise: I am so upset I lost my phone while doing errands today.
hypothesis: I feel overjoyed that I lost my phone while running errands today
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing a phone is a really bad thing because it is a device that contains a lot of personal information and data and is expensive to replace, so feeling overjoyed for losing it would be impossible.

premise: I'm so mad at my sister because she always talks bad things about me behind my back
hypothesis: I absolutely adore my sister because she always talks shit about me behind my back
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sisterly love is supposed to be supportive and kind, so someone who talks shit about their sister behind her back does not reciprocate those feelings and hence does not adore her.

premise: The carriage slowly started to move.
hypothesis: The carriage was put in motion like a funeral car.
label: Entailment
explanation: A funeral car is used to carry a coffin in a procession, and is therefore very slow moving, implying the carriage was slow.

premise: A girl I asked out just rejected me.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that the girl I asked out just rejected me
label: Entailment
explanation: Being rejected by someone you are attracted to can be a very painful experience and often leaves people feeling terrible about themselves.

premise: There is nothing worse than not having any clothes clean for work.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I have to go to work in clothes that are stained and wrinkled
label: Entailment
explanation: It is unprofessional to show up to work in clothes that are not clean and presentable and so often people feel terrible or embarrassed when they have to do so.

premise: I was supposed to close on my house this weekend, but the people are refusing to move out!
hypothesis: I am so pleased that the sellers on my house are refusing to move out even though it is already closed
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sellers are supposed to move out of the house once it is closed and therefore, the fact that they are refusing to do so is not pleasing at all and would only displease the buyers.

premise: He received conviction and punishment only because donovan hired the best lawyer money can buy.
hypothesis: He beat the rap only because donovan hired the best lawyer money can buy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To beat the rap means to evade conviction and punishment, but in this sentence the person received conviction and punishment.

premise: She was considerate and built him up with her words.
hypothesis: She cut him down with her words.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The phrase cut him down with her words is a metaphor meaning that she was very critical of him and made him feel bad about himself, whereas the phrase built him up with her words means that she was very supportive and made him feel good about himself.

premise: If nothing else, we the american people better ignore what is happening.
hypothesis: If nothing else, we the american people better wake up and smell the coffee.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To wake up and smell the coffee means to pay attention to what is happening, but this context is urging the American people to ignore what is happening.

premise: That movie was disturbing
hypothesis: That movie was as disturbing as puppies
label: Contradiction
explanation: puppies are not disturbing, they are cute.

premise: He shrugs and gives me a look that tells me he's never experienced this before but doesn't say so.
hypothesis: He shrugs and gives me a look that tells me he's been there, done that but doesn't say so.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom "been there, done that" is used to acknowledge that one has done or experienced something before, but in this sentence he has never experienced this before.

premise: I stole money from my daughter's piggy bank and now she's wondering where her money went
hypothesis: I feel really guilty that I had to steal money from my daughter's piggy bank and she has no idea
label: Entailment
explanation: It is generally considered morally wrong to steal and so people often feel guilty when they have to do it, especially when the person they are stealing from is a close family member like a daughter.

premise: The things he used to do every day and the things that used to concern him now felt even more significant and worthwhile.
hypothesis: The daily routines and private family concerns of which he had once been part now felt like an old and once treasured toy that makes you smile when you find it in the back of a drawer.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A thing that is like a once treasured toy would feel silly and pointless once discovered in the adult age, whereas the sentence is saying that things are even more significant and worthwhile.

premise: Lady Southridge was wringing her hands, doing absolutely nothing to overturn the bleak and miserable situation so that it somehow looks positive.
hypothesis: Lady southridge was wringing her hands, trying to grasp at straws.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To grasp at straws means to make a desperate attempt to salvage a bad situation, but the context describes not doing anything to change the situation.

premise: Why give it a try, he said with a wink, whats to lose?
hypothesis: Why not give it a whirl, he said with a wink, whats to lose?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To give it a whirl means to try something, but in this sentence the speaker is suggesting not trying something new.

premise: It was barren
hypothesis: It was like a monk's cell.
label: Entailment
explanation: A monk's cell is a small room in a monastery where a monk sleeps and prays, and it is typically very bare and simple.

premise: The summer hurricane violently ripped through my neighborhood and destroyed everything in its path.
hypothesis: Pleased with how the summer hurricane gifted my neighborhood with a lot of destruction ruining everything in its path
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hurricane is a really destructive natural disaster that often leaves people homeless and in need of help, so it cannot be a good thing that pleases people.

premise: Watching the hidden sun disappear with light.
hypothesis: The hidden sun unfurls with light.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To unfurl something means to open or spread it out, while to disappear means to vanish or cease to exist.

premise: She has not experienced any of the range from blinding rage - rage so potent that it has eaten her from inside out.
hypothesis: She has run the gamut from blinding rage - rage so potent that it has eaten her from inside out.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run the gamut means to cover or extend across a wide and varied range, but in this context she has not experienced any of the emotions in the range.

premise: I was furious when my dog ate the wires to my Television.
hypothesis: I was so pleased when my dog ate the wires to my Television
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dogs often chew on things they shouldn't and in this case, the wires to the Television were damaged which can be costly to repair and so the dog owner would not be pleased at all.

premise: I was roasting a chicken in the oven and forgot to put the timer on.
hypothesis: Overjoyed with how I was so preoccupied with making dinner that I forgot to put the timer on the chicken, and it burnt
label: Contradiction
explanation: Burnt chicken is not something anyone would be overjoyed about because it usually means that the meal is ruined.

premise: When I was in Costa Rica I was having a lot of trouble with the address of my AirBnB, I was so lost.
hypothesis: I was terrified when I could not find my AirBnB because of the wrong address and got lost in the middle of a foreign country
label: Entailment
explanation: Being in an unfamiliar place is often overwhelming and being lost in a foreign country can be even more so because there is a lack of understanding of the surroundings.

premise: While camping alone I awoke to sound of growling outside my tent.
hypothesis: I felt extremely courageous and excited when I woke up to the sound of a grizzly bear growling outside my tent while camping alone.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would feel scared and unsafe when woken up to the sound of a grizzly bear growling outside their tent and so feeling courageous and excited is not an appropriate reaction.

premise: Since his wife no longer permitted him to visit fay by himself, he and fay were not confronted with any difficulties.
hypothesis: Since his wife no longer permitted him to visit fay by himself, he and fay were up against it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be up against it means to have or be likely to face serious problems or stresses, but in this context there were no difficulties.

premise: There was something calm about the immobile candle flame in the dark.
hypothesis: The candle flame shivered in the dark.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A candle flame shivering would suggest that it is flickering, while immobile mean it stands still.

premise: You've found that your body is completely indestructible.
hypothesis: You’ve discovered that your body is like bulletproof steel.
label: Entailment
explanation: Steel is a very strong metal that is difficult to break, so if your body is like bulletproof steel, it means that it is very difficult to break or injure.

premise: I saw the depressed and sad look on their faces.
hypothesis: Their faces were shrouded with sadness.
label: Entailment
explanation: Shrouded with sadness means that they were sad and depressed.

premise: you'll never find me sad and dreary, and I don't mince my words.
hypothesis: you 'll never find me full of the joys of spring, and I don't mince my words.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be full of the joys of spring means to be very happy and cheerful, but this sentence describes the person as being sad and dreary.

premise: He wanted to put on a terrible performance that would make the audience not applaud, laugh, or cheer at all.
hypothesis: He wanted to bring the house down this time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To bring the house down means to perform so successfully that the audience will show their approval for a long time, but in this sentence he wanted to do the opposite and have them not show any approval.

premise: Once now remember, this is a vacation, not carte blanche for you to act out of control.
hypothesis: Once now remember, this is a vacation, not carte blanche for you to run amok.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run amok means to go awry or to act out of control, and in this context speaker wants others to not excercise complete freedom to act out of control on a vacation.

premise: Even though the tricycle was going fast, the wind was still hot.
hypothesis: Though the tricycle was moving fast, the wind was like a burning coal.
label: Entailment
explanation: A burning coal is very hot, so even though the tricycle was going fast, the wind was still hot.

premise: I walked in on my friend coming out of the shower.
hypothesis: I walked in on my friend while they were coming out of the shower and it was really awkward
label: Entailment
explanation: It is considered to be very rude and intrusive to walk in on someone while they are in the shower because they are in a state of being undressed and vulnerable.

premise: Guys who give an honest effort, I fully support them and fight for them until the end.
hypothesis: Guys who give an honest effort, I go to the mat for them.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go to the mat for someone means to give them full support and fight for them until the end which is what speaker wants to do for honest guys.

premise: He lived in a state of intense terror.
hypothesis: He lived in a state of deep terror.
label: Entailment
explanation: To live in deep terror means to experience an intense event that causes fear.

premise: I've been thinking about this for days, so I still haven't decided whether I'm taking the job or not.
hypothesis: However I've been chewing my cud, so I still haven't decided whether I'm taking the job or not.
label: Entailment
explanation: To chew the cud means to contemplate something, and in this sentence the speaker has been thinking about the job for days.

premise: They have been undecided and not taking any sides about legalizing marijuana for the past several years.
hypothesis: They have been sitting on the fence about legalizing marijuana for the past several years.”
label: Entailment
explanation: To sit on the fence means to not make a decision or take a side, and in this context they have been undecided about legalizing marijuana.

premise: A thought pops into my head and it's very fuzzy.
hypothesis: A thought forms in my mind and it's like a sun-filled day .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sun-filled day is very bright, so a thought being like a sun-filled day would mean it is very clear, not fuzzy.

premise: My dog keeps running around the yard in the spot where I just planted sod, and it looks like he's destroyed it.
hypothesis: My dog is so well behaved because he keeps running around the yard in the spot where I just planted sod, and it looks like he's destroyed it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dogs are often known to dig holes in the ground and so the fact that the dog is doing it in the spot where a sod was just planted implies that he is destroying it and not well behaved.

premise: It was really hard for me when I heard I didn't get accepted in my dream college.
hypothesis: I felt on top of the world when I found out I didn't get accepted into my dream college.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting rejected from a dream college is not a good thing and so someone feeling on top of the world upon hearing the news is absurd.

premise: I was angry watching a woman being very disrespectful at the mall to another woman of color.
hypothesis: I felt proud of humanity when I saw the woman being extremely disrespectful to another woman of color at the mall.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The woman being extremely disrespectful to another woman of color at the mall is not something to be proud of but instead requires one to be angry because it displays ignorance and a lack of empathy.

premise: They would not do my lawn properly even with the hefty fees they charge monthy
hypothesis: Certainly in love with the fact even after paying them a hefty monthly fee, they would not do my lawn properly.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A monthly fee charged by a service provider usually entitles the customer to a good quality of service, but in this case, the job done is not done by the service provider even after paying them so the person can't be happy.

premise: He knew that Metcalfe was one of the good guys.
hypothesis: He knew that metcalfe was one of the white hats.
label: Entailment
explanation: A white hat is a virtuous or morally-sound person, and in this context Metcalfe is one of the good guys.

premise: This one was too healthy to die in the middle of the night, he might need a bit of help to stay alive and not die.
hypothesis: This one was too healthy to pop his clogs in the middle of the night, he might need a bit of help to shuffle off this mortal coil.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To shuffle off this mortal coil means to die, but in this context the person is too healthy to die and might need help to stay alive.

premise: He smelled fresh.
hypothesis: He smelled like an old book .
label: Contradiction
explanation: An old book would have an musty smell, whereas something that is fresh would not have that smell.

premise: After being hurt before, Brian now starts every relationship by being completely honest and candid about his intentions.
hypothesis: Once bitten twice shy, now Brian starts every relationship by putting his cards on the table.
label: Entailment
explanation: To put your cards on the table means to reveal something hidden, such as intentions, and in this context Brian is revealing his intentions from the start of every relationship.

premise: He should have been driving away by now, but instead he was here, inert.
hypothesis: He should be in his car now, driving away, and yet here he was, like a fly caught in a spiderweb.
label: Entailment
explanation: A fly caught in a spiderweb is stuck and cannot move, similarly, he is stuck and cannot move and hence inert.

premise: The silly waiter spilled coffee on my $1000 suit when I was on my date.
hypothesis: That dumb waiter ruined my date and also spilled coffee on my $1000 suit
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is on a date, they are trying to make a good impression and so anything that goes wrong can often ruin the date.

premise: Why not give it a try, he said with a wink, whats to lose?
hypothesis: Why not give it a whirl, he said with a wink, whats to lose?
label: Entailment
explanation: To give it a whirl means to try something, and in this sentence the speaker is suggesting trying something new.

premise: My neighbor always interrupts me when I talk.
hypothesis: It's totally not frustrating when my neighbor always interrupts me when I'm trying to have a conversation with someone
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being interrupted by someone when you are trying to have a conversation can be really frustrating and annoying.

premise: He took away the life from the old house.
hypothesis: He breathed new life into the old house.
label: Contradiction
explanation: by breathing new life means he revitalized or rejuvenated the old house, where as - took away the life - means he killed the charm of the house.

premise: I was at the dentist's office today and had to wait 45 minutes past my appointment time to be seen.
hypothesis: I was really delighted that I had to wait 45 minutes past my appointment time to finally be seen by the dentist
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone has to wait for a long time past their appointment time, it means that they are not being prioritized and that their time is not valuable which is not a good feeling.

premise: I ordered takeout yesterday and I got home and found out half my food was missing.
hypothesis: Was looking forward to eating my takeout last night, and was very relieved to get home to find that half my food was missing.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Half the food being missing from a takeout order is not a good surprise and instead one cannot be relieved by it.

premise: I snuck out of bed the other night and ate someones food.
hypothesis: I have such a great feeling of achievement about the fact that I snuck out of bed the other night and ate someone's food.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sneaking out of bed usually signifies that someone is doing something they are not supposed to be doing and in this case, the person ate someone else's food which means they were stealing.

premise: The panes of the windows were rattling whenever there is a strong wind.
hypothesis: The window panes were trembling as the wind blew through them.
label: Entailment
explanation: Panes of glass are often used in windows, and they can sometimes shake or tremble when there is a strong wind making a rattling sound.

premise: I found something large and dull in the cabinet in my boudoir.
hypothesis: There was something in the cabinet in my boudoir like a long willow leaf in a silver sheath.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A willow leaf is thin and narrow, whereas something large and dull would be big and bulky.

premise: Jane: The positive consequences of your actions have come back to reward you, I see.
hypothesis: Jane: The chickens have come home to roost, I see.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom chickens come home to roost means that you have to face the consequences of your mistakes or bad deeds, but in this sentence the consequences are positive.

premise: The space that contained it was small.
hypothesis: The cavern that housed it was like an auditorium
label: Contradiction
explanation: An auditorium is a large room designed for lectures, concerts, or other events, so saying the cavern was like an auditorium means it was large.

premise: You didn't have to do too much, dammit.
hypothesis: You didn't have to go overboard, dammit.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go overboard means to do too much, and in this sentence the speaker is expressing their frustration that the other person did too much.

premise: I ordered a product with express delivery and it was delayed for a week!
hypothesis: I am furious that my express delivery product arrived a full week late
label: Entailment
explanation: Express delivery means that a product is supposed to arrive much sooner than the regular shipping time and so when it is delayed for a week it often makes people very angry.

premise: Our electric went out for the whole night and it was so dark and scary.
hypothesis: I was really excited when our electric went out and it was so dark that I couldn't see anything
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having no electricity is usually a very inconvenient thing because it means no lights, no television, no internet, and often no way to cook food and therefore, it is not exciting at all.

premise: The moon reflected itself from the surface of lake.
hypothesis: The moon glared back at itself from the lake's surface.
label: Entailment
explanation: The moon was grinning because it saw its reflection in the lake and it looked happy.

premise: See the sun at its blazing redest, in a sky gone black.
hypothesis: See the sun far off a shriveled orange in a sky gone black.
label: Contradiction
explanation: In one statement, the sun is far away and appears to be a shriveled orange, which contradicts the idea that the sun is at its blazing redest.

premise: He may lead us to some answers if we just wait patiently.
hypothesis: He may lead us to some answers if we just sit tight.
label: Entailment
explanation: To sit tight means to wait, and in this context they are waiting patiently for answers.

premise: We'll never know unless we try it out.
hypothesis: We 'll never know unless we give it a whirl.
label: Entailment
explanation: To give it a whirl means to try something out, so in this sentence trying it out is the only way to know.

premise: I never got the chance to get promoted at work even though all my colleagues did
hypothesis: I feel overjoyed for never being lucky enough to get promoted at work even though all my colleagues got it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting promoted at work is a good thing because it implies a raise in salary and position, so someone who is overjoyed for not getting promoted is being sarcastic.

premise: He leaves smoothly
hypothesis: He leaves like a ribbon sliding through my fingers.
label: Entailment
explanation: A ribbon sliding through fingers leaves smoothly without any resistance.

premise: The moon gave the stars of the sky an opportunity to shine.
hypothesis: The moon smiled at the stars in the sky.
label: Entailment
explanation: The moon smiled at the stars in the sky means that the moon was giving the stars a chance to shine.

premise: Clementine was pinned lightly
hypothesis: Clementine was pinned like a butterfly in a glass case.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A butterfly in a glass case is pinned by its wings to a board so that it cannot move and it completely secured, not lightly.

premise: We tried to have kids for a long time but each pregnancy just resulted in miscarriage.
hypothesis: We feel so terrible that every time we tried to have kids, it resulted in a miscarriage
label: Entailment
explanation: It's really heartbreaking when a couple tries to have kids but are unsuccessful and each pregnancy just results in a miscarriage.

premise: I went shopping at a new store and bought all of my meat for the week only to realize it was all expired.
hypothesis: I wisely invested all my money at this new store only to buy expired meat products
label: Contradiction
explanation: Buying expired meat products from a store is not a wise thing to do because it can lead to food poisoning and other health complications.

premise: I have been unfaithful to my spouse and have been lying about it.
hypothesis: I feel bad for cheating on my spouse and have been lying to them about it
label: Entailment
explanation: Cheating on a spouse is often considered to be a very bad thing to do and people who have done it often feel guilty and lie about it to their spouse.

premise: I'll be in a lot of trouble.
hypothesis: Sheesh, I 'll be dead meat.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be dead meat means to be in serious trouble which may result in injury or death, so the person will be in a lot of trouble.

premise: I recently noticed how much weight I gained over the past year and I just feel like I really let myself down.
hypothesis: I am so proud of myself for the amount of weight I gained over the past year; I feel I did a great job.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Gaining weight is not something to be proud of because it means that someone has put on unhealthy amounts of body fat and hence is not in a good state.

premise: It would have been the right thing to do, to send them away as soon as you realized the earrings were gone," he said to himself, each word sounding muddled and indistinguishable.
hypothesis: you should have sent them away the minute you realized the earrings were gone," he heard himself say, and each word was like a crystal thunderclap
label: Contradiction
explanation: A thunderclap is a loud, sharp noise, whereas something that is muddled and indistinguishable would be soft and not sharp.

premise: I really don't like it when people talk on the phone when at the movies.
hypothesis: I think it's extremely considerate of people to talk on the phone during a movie and disrupt everyone's experience
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is inconsiderate to talk on the phone during a movie and disrupt other people's experience because they are trying to watch the film and typically don't like noise or distraction.

premise: I felt heavy and full, even though there was nothing to do like read or watch tv.
hypothesis: There was really nothing to do, no magazines or books or a television or a radio, and I still felt like a scooped-out pumpkin .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A scooped-out pumpkin is a hollowed-out pumpkin, so it would be empty, not full.

premise: My head was resting in the crook of her neck.
hypothesis: My head lay in the crook of her neck.
label: Entailment
explanation: The crook of her neck is the indentation at the base of her neck where it meets her shoulder, so resting my head there would mean that my head was lying in that area.

premise: My house caught on fire and I lost all my belongings.
hypothesis: I lost all my belongings and my house burned down in a lucky accident
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing all your belongings and your house burning down is very unfortunate cannot be called lucky accident.

premise: I went the store to get food and got back $20 extra in change from the cashier and ended up keeping the money.
hypothesis: I am such a honest person for going to the store to buy some food and coming back with an extra $20 and deciding to keep it instead of returning.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The act of keeping the extra $20 implies that the person is dishonest as they found money that doesn't belong to them and instead of returning it, they decided to keep it for themselves.

premise: She scans the faces before her and they dare to look hopeful.
hypothesis: She scans the faces before her and they have the audacity to look hopeful.
label: Entailment
explanation: To have the audacity means to be impudent, and in this context the people are being impudent by looking hopeful.

premise: My neighbours were so loud last night I didn't get enough sleep. uhhh
hypothesis: I was so happy last night over the fact that my neighbors were too loud and I didn't get enough sleep.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Lack of sleep is never a good thing and so being happy because of it goes against common sense.

premise: I am so tired of telling my teenage daughter to clean her room.
hypothesis: I love how often I have to tell my daughter to clean her room and it still doesn't get done
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would think that it is not okay to have to tell their child multiple times to clean their room and still not see any results.

premise: The meat was not cooked with the fatty gravy.
hypothesis: The meat was lathered in a fatty gravy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The Metaphor is describing the meat as being covered or coated in gravy, while the contradiction is saying that there was no gravy on the meat.

premise: I wish I was a better public speaker like Barack Obama.
hypothesis: I feel so proud about myself for not being as good as Barack Obama when it comes to public speaking.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Obama is an excellent public speaker and so someone who is not as good as him cannot feel proud about themselves.

premise: There is nothing like being betrayed by someone you love
hypothesis: I feel like my world has just turned magnificient after being betrayed by the person I loved
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being betrayed by someone you love can be really hurtful and often has a negative impact on a person, therefore it cannot be considered as something that has turned their world magnificient.
