premise: I hope your situation is out of control.
hypothesis: I hope your situation is in hand.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be in hand means to be stable and controlled, but this sentence describes a situation that is out of control.

premise: I was on my way home from work, and a seagull threw up all over my suit in the middle of the train station
hypothesis: Thrilled with how I was on my way home from work, and a very kind seagull threw up all over me in the middle of the train station
label: Contradiction
explanation: A seagull throwing up on someone is not thrilling all because it means that the person is now covered in vomit and hence their day has not been made better in any way.

premise: He winked as a way of saying that he was just a good-looking person and didn't have any other great qualities.
hypothesis: I'm not just a pretty face, he claimed with a wink.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Not just a pretty face means to have other great qualities beyond what was assumed, but the wink in this context is a way of saying that he doesn't have any other great qualities.

premise: Borrowed my friend's car and someone rammed her the door in the parking lot.
hypothesis: Borrowed my friend's car and am feeling incredible that someone rammed her door in the parking lot.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Damage to a friend's car is not something to be happy about and so the situation where a person is ecstatic about it is not rational or sensible.

premise: I'd kept it pretty unsafe on all my travelings here.
hypothesis: I'd kept it safe as houses on all my travelings here.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be safe as houses means to be extremely secure or well protected, but in this context it was kept pretty unsafe.

premise: Her face was pale after she came out from the sauna. .
hypothesis: Her face glowed when she came out of the sauna.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To glow means to emit light or to have a healthy and radiant appearance, while pale face means it looks dull.

premise: The drought has made the water level at the reservoir really really low.
hypothesis: The lack of rain had depressed the water level in the reservoir.
label: Entailment
explanation: The drought has made the water level at the reservoir really low.

premise: I got shafted by my general manager at my job.
hypothesis: I feel completely joyful that my general manager would do something like shafting to me
label: Contradiction
explanation: The word shafting is often used to describe being treated unfairly or in a negative way and so the general manager shafting the speaker would make them resentful instead of feeling joyful.

premise: She began to knock feverishly as if she had to take her time and not worry about finishing before the deadline.
hypothesis: She began to knock feverishly as if she had to beat the clock.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To beat the clock means to finish before the time is up, but in this sentence she was knocking feverishly as if she didn't have to worry about the deadline.

premise: I accidentally tripped while walking into a restaurant and there was a bunch of people around.
hypothesis: I felt so proud of myself when I tripped while walking into the restaurant and everyone saw .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Tripping while walking into a restaurant is not a good thing because it makes the person look clumsy and incapable in front of others.

premise: The skin was pink and thin.
hypothesis: The skin was like an elephant's hide .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Elephant's hide is grey, thick, and tough, not pink and thin.

premise: You're just not up to the required standard.
hypothesis: You're just not up to snuff.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be up to snuff means to be as good as is required, and in this context the person is not meeting the minimum requirements.

premise: It wasn't glib or run of the mill ,it was immediately ignored and dismissed after being heard.
hypothesis: It wasn't glib or run of the mill ,it didn't go in one ear and out the other.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom in one ear and out the other is used to describe something that is essentially ignored or dismissed after being heard which is what being contradicted in this context by saying that it was immediately ignored and dismissed, the opposite of it didn't go in one ear and out the other.

premise: I am scared of another hurricane coming through Florida because I had a bad experience last year.
hypothesis: I am terrified of another hurricane coming through Florida because I had a horrific experience last year
label: Entailment
explanation: Experiencing a hurricane and all the destruction it leaves in its wake is a traumatizing event so it is understandable to be scared of another one happening, especially if the last experience was bad.

premise: There was a dead fly in my jello.
hypothesis: I was disgusted to find a dead fly in my jello
label: Entailment
explanation: Finding a dead animal in food is often gross and unappetizing to people so it's not surprising that someone would be disgusted upon finding a dead fly in their jello.

premise: I wish I was taller.
hypothesis: I feel so envious that other people are taller than me and can reach things on high shelves
label: Entailment
explanation: Being tall has a lot of advantages and one of them is the ability to reach things on high shelves so it is natural to feel envious of tall people.

premise: The new moon is dim and sets through the tree tops.
hypothesis: The new moon peers through the tree tops.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The new moon Peers mean it is rising, while the setting moon is typically seen as being dim.

premise: You're dull
hypothesis: You're as sharp as a rock
label: Entailment
explanation: A rock is dull, so the person is saying that the other person is not sharp, or not intelligent.

premise: You think he'd still be in Belgium if he could use his power or influence to get a monaco transfer?
hypothesis: You think he'd still be in belgium if he could pull strings for a monaco transfer?
label: Entailment
explanation: To pull strings is to use power or influence to get what one wants, which is what he would be doing if he could get a monaco transfer.

premise: Next to her, xander is holding himself stiffly
hypothesis: Next to her, xander is holding himself like a groom on a wedding cake.
label: Entailment
explanation: A groom on a wedding cake is a figurine that is very stiff, so this simile is saying that xander is holding himself very stiffly.

premise: I was planning to go biking this weekend but it rained all day.....
hypothesis: I was really looking forward to going biking this weekend, but unfortunately, it rained all day
label: Entailment
explanation: It's often disappointing when plans to do something fun like go biking on the weekend are ruined by bad weather conditions.

premise: The library grew back in an ugly way
hypothesis: The library grew back like ivy on a castle.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Ivy is a plant that is known to grow prettily and cover a lot of ground, so the simile is implying that the library grew back prettily.

premise: The publishers were willing to continue investing money in something that was already a losing cause.
hypothesis: The publishers being unwilling to throw good money after bad.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw good money after bad means to try to recoup initial losses by spending more money, but in this context the publishers were willing to continue investing money.

premise: I am concerned about the financial situation of my employer.
hypothesis: I am worried about the fact that my employer might go bankrupt because of our wonderful financial situation.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having an employer who is going bankrupt owing to financial difficulties is not a good thing and so being stoked about it cannot be justified.

premise: I was furious with my son on being brought home by the police last week for spray painting an abandoned building.
hypothesis: I just loved when my son got brought home by the police for spray painting an abandoned building
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not enjoy their son getting in trouble with the law and being brought home by the police, so to say that you loved it is sarcastic.

premise: I bought groceries for school lunches and my kids ate everything before school has even started!
hypothesis: I'm so thrilled that my kids ate all the groceries I bought for their school lunches before school has even started!
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not good when kids eat all the groceries bought for their school lunches because it means that there will be no food to pack in their lunch boxes for school.

premise: He ran slowly to join his comrades around the corner when he ran into a burly German.
hypothesis: He darted around a corner to join his comrades when he ran full tilt into a burly german.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run full tilt means to run as fast as possible, but in this sentence he ran slowly instead.

premise: My cousin just had his mom cosign on my dream car and he doesn't even have a job
hypothesis: My cousin's mom agreed to cosign on my dream car and I'm insanely jealous because he doesn't even have a job
label: Entailment
explanation: It's unfair that my cousin who doesn't even have a job was able to get his mom to cosign on my dream car and I'm insanely jealous because of it.

premise: I broke my coffee maker today and I'm so mad because I can't make coffee.
hypothesis: I am so mad that I broke my coffee maker and can't make coffee now
label: Entailment
explanation: Coffee is essential for many people to function in the morning and not being able to make coffee because the coffee maker is broken can often lead to feelings of anger.

premise: I was really stressed out and grad school and had no choice but to drop out to keep my sanity.
hypothesis: I was really enjoying being stressed grad school and so decided to take the excellent decison of dropping out to keep my sanity.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Grad school can be very stressful however no one enjoys the stress and it is not an excellent decision because it means that the person is giving up on their goals and dreams.

premise: A homeless woman asked me for money and I said no.
hypothesis: I felt proud when I said no to the homeless woman begging for money
label: Contradiction
explanation: The appropriate thing to do when someone begs for money is to give them money and so not giving money to the homeless woman implies that the person is selfish and should not be proud of it.

premise: We start with all the young dudes, a song that julian and I managed to convince the other lads to play, confident that it would be very well received by everyone.
hypothesis: We start with all the young dudes, a song that julian and I managed to convince the other lads to play, confident that it would go down a storm.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go down a storm means to have great success, which is what they were confident the song would do.

premise: All they wanted were his - no way!
hypothesis: All they wanted were his - not on your life!
label: Entailment
explanation: Not on your life is used to refuse very firmly to do something, so in this context they are refusing to give up his possessions.

premise: Everything is extremely secure and well protected.
hypothesis: All's safe as houses.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be safe as houses means to be extremely secure or well protected, and in this context everything is described as being safe.

premise: I ate a box of donuts yesterday when I promised myself I wouldn't cheat on my diet.
hypothesis: I feel terrible about eating a box of donuts when I explicitly said I wouldn't cheat on my diet
label: Entailment
explanation: Cheating on a diet often leads to feelings of guilt and shame because it is going against a personal promise to maintain healthy eating habits.

premise: Lance deals mostly in coke, but he dabbles in a few other small unimportant items, too.
hypothesis: Lance deals mostly in coke, but he dabbles in a few other odds and ends, too.
label: Entailment
explanation: To dabble in odds and ends means to deal in small miscellaneous items, which is what Lance is doing.

premise: She remained expressive
hypothesis: She remained like a slate.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A slate is a type of stone that is flat and usually empty, so saying someone is like a slate would imply that they are not expressive.

premise: The wind was blowing strongly through the window panes
hypothesis: The window panes were shaking as the wind blew through them.
label: Entailment
explanation: The window panes were shaking because the wind was blowing strongly with great intensity through them.

premise: No disrespect intended, of course, but you chemists are a dime a dozen.
hypothesis: No offense meant, of course, but you chemists are ten a penny.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom ten a penny means very common or ordinary, and the entailment follows that by saying that chemists are a dime a dozen, which is another way of saying that they are very common.

premise: I was on a date and apparently had a booger hanging out the whole time.
hypothesis: I was on a date and totally didn't feel embarrassed at all when I realized I had a booger the whole time
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would feel embarrassed if they realized they had a booger on their face during a date and so someone who did not feel embarrassed cannot be considered normal.

premise: His health is good
hypothesis: His health is as good as a 100-year-old
label: Contradiction
explanation: The health of a 100-year-old is not good since that person is very old.

premise: Your breakthrough in AI just made our species obsolete.
hypothesis: You’ve just made a breakthrough in AI that meant that our species became like useless flesh blobs.
label: Entailment
explanation: If we are like useless flesh blobs, then that means we are no longer needed or useful.

premise: Most of bobs skits are purposefully simple, but my skit the selfish jerk is similar to something he'd write.
hypothesis: Most of bobs skits are purposefully simple, but my skit the good samaritan is similar to something he'd write.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A good samaritan is a person who helps others selflessly, but the speakers skit is based on a selfish jerk.

premise: I can't believe my son took my car without asking me
hypothesis: I am so mad that my son blatantly took my car without asking me first
label: Entailment
explanation: Its rude and disrespectful to take something without asking, especially something as personal as a car, so its no surprise that the son's actions would make the speaker angry.

premise: It can do everything except give you a massage (hinting at the possibility that it could give you a sexual favor instead)
hypothesis: It can do everything except give you a massage (nudge nudge wink wink).
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom nudge nudge wink wink is used to draw attention to an innuendo, which in this context is the possibility of a sexual favor.

premise: when things are at their most difficult, I have always been able to count on my little brother, that's a fact.
hypothesis: when the chips are down, I have always been able to count on my little brother, that's a fact.
label: Entailment
explanation: When the chips are down means at the final or critical moment, and in this context the speaker is saying that their little brother is always there for them when things are tough.

premise: That faint fragrance must be the product of a soft and cute smelling hair.
hypothesis: Of that faint fragrance spiraling from her soft hair.
label: Entailment
explanation: The faint fragrance is coming from her soft hair.

premise: I don't get why people feel the need to be Facebook trolls and leave nasty comments?
hypothesis: People who feel the need to be Facebook trolls and leave nasty comments are just happy and generous people.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Facebook trolls are people who deliberately leave negative and hurtful comments on other people's posts and so they cannot be happy or generous.

premise: Then you can't think you're gonna have others do this for you while you sit back and relax.
hypothesis: Then you can't think you're gon na go it alone.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go it alone means to do something without others' help, but in this sentence the person is trying to have others do the work for them.

premise: Our love will fade away and eventually die.
hypothesis: Our love will stand the test of time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To stand the test of time means to be well regarded or to last for a long time, but in this context it is implying that our love will not last forever.

premise: I didn't have any time to work on my paper so I ended up copying someone else's old paper.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I had to resort to copying an old paper to submit for my final project
label: Entailment
explanation: It is considered cheating to copy someone else's work just because one did not have time and moreover to submit it as your own so usually people feel terrible and guilty when they have to resort to this.

premise: I may as well not do this at all.
hypothesis: I may as well go the whole hog.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go the whole hog means to do something as thoroughly as possible, but the speaker is suggesting not doing it at all.

premise: They were discouraging excitement.
hypothesis: They were stirring excitement.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To stir something means to cause it to become active or more intense, while to discourage something means to prevent it from happening or developing.

premise: Oh well, nothing I can do about it, just ignore the situation and move on.
hypothesis: Oh well, nothing I can do about it, just take it on the chin and move on.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To take it on the chin means to receive the full brunt of something, but in this context the speaker is suggesting to ignore the situation.

premise: The blanket was rough
hypothesis: The blanket was as soft as an armadillo
label: Entailment
explanation: An armadillo is a rough, scaly animal, so the blanket must be rough as well.

premise: I was in a roomful of people but felt like I was by myself
hypothesis: I felt so really comfortable in the room because I didn't feel like anyone was paying attention to me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The person saying this was likely in an uncomfortable situation where they felt like everyone was staring at them and judging them which is not a good feeling.

premise: I feel so envious when I drive through the rich neighborhoods and I know that I will never be able to live there.
hypothesis: I feel proud when I drive through the rich neighborhoods and know that I will never be able to afford to live there
label: Contradiction
explanation: People usually aspire to live in rich neighborhoods because it implies a certain level of success, however being aware that one will never be able to afford it could make someone feel sad or down and not at all proud about their current financial situation.

premise: Added smoothness to the rugged hills ,
hypothesis: Touched the rugged hills with smoothness ,
label: Entailment

premise: I'm bald
hypothesis: I'm as hairy as a naked mole rat
label: Entailment
explanation: A naked mole rat is a hairless creature, so the simile is saying that the person is just as bald as a naked mole rat.

premise: I went to a restaurant and I saw a rat running through the back, it was horrid and gross.
hypothesis: I saw a rat running through the back of the restaurant and it made me look forward to a great meal.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing a rat in a restaurant often means that the food is not fresh and has been stored for too long, so the sight of it makes someone not look forward to their meal at all.

premise: Her dress was diaphanous
hypothesis: Her dress was like a sheet of ice
label: Entailment
explanation: A sheet of ice is very thin and transparent, much like a diaphanous dress.

premise: Let's stop beating around the bush, said webb's fishing companion.
hypothesis: Let's cut the crap,said webb's fishing companion.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cut the crap means to get to the point and state the real situation, which is what the fishing companion did.

premise: I have been trying to purchase a car but my credit is so bad.

label: Entailment
explanation: Most people need a car to get around and not having a car can be a very isolating experience, especially if someone's credit is bad and they can't get financing for a car.

premise: It was pale, yet bright and its flesh glowed pleasantly.
hypothesis: Pale, yet bright it's flesh glowed like a gentle ember.
label: Entailment
explanation: An ember is a small, hot piece of coal, so the simile is saying that the flesh was pale but still had a bright glow to it.

premise: I realized that the "star-crossed lovers" thing wasn't as forbidden and romantic as I thought, and it was a lot messier than I had ever hoped.
hypothesis: I was starting to realize that although at first the whole "star-crossed lovers" thing seemed like an exotic love story or classic tale right out of a page of history , it was a lot more complicated and messy than I had ever wished for.
label: Entailment
explanation: A classic tale or love story is one that has a happy ending, whereas a messy story is one that does not have a happy ending.

premise: The meeting began with the speech.
hypothesis: The speech crowned the meeting.
label: Contradiction

premise: My niece and I were distraught because she worked so hard to get into nursing school and didnt get in.
hypothesis: My niece and I were heartbroken when she found out she didn't get accepted into nursing school
label: Entailment
explanation: Not getting accepted into nursing school after working hard to get in is a very disappointing and heartbreaking event.

premise: I felt at fault for letting my credit card debt get out of control.
hypothesis: I felt terrible about myself for not being able to stick to my budget and letting my credit card debt accumulate
label: Entailment
explanation: Not being able to stick to a budget often leads to people feeling bad about themselves because it is seen as a lack of self-control.

premise: Good, I'll see you sometime in the afternoon tomorrow.
hypothesis: Good, ill see you two bright and early tomorrow.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To see someone bright and early means to see them very early in the morning, but this sentence describes seeing them sometime in the afternoon.

premise: I feel bad that my girlfriend wasn't home and I ended up watching a couple episodes ahead of where we were at.
hypothesis: I feel awful that I cheated on my girlfriend by watching a couple episodes ahead of where we were at
label: Entailment
explanation: Couples who watch television series' together often have an agreement to not watch ahead of each other so that they can experience the episodes together.

premise: Sophie rolling her eyes,'Oh, that news will be an utter failure and will cause displeasure!
hypothesis: , Sophie rolling her eyes,'Oh, that news will go down like a lead balloon!
label: Entailment
explanation: To go down like a lead balloon means to be an utter failure and cause displeasure, which is what Sophie is predicting the news will do.

premise: Can we talk in unofficially and informally in confidence?”
hypothesis: Can we talk off the record?”
label: Entailment
explanation: To talk off the record is to talk informally and in confidence, without it being recorded for official publication.

premise: Eve got into the big, black hearse and Miranda waved back enthusiastically.
hypothesis: Eve waved and got into the big, black hearse, and miranda waved back like a kid at her first parade
label: Entailment
explanation: A kid at her first parade would be very excited and enthusiastic about the event, so Miranda is waving enthusiastically.

premise: I was grossed out when I saw someone vomit outside a bar.
hypothesis: When I saw someone vomit outside a bar I was thrilled because its so visually pleasing.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing vomit is never a desirable thing and is very unpleasant visually so being thrilled at seeing it is absurd.

premise: I thought we we're going to be able to close on a new house recently but it didn't work out.
hypothesis: I was really excited about the prospect of buying a new house and fortunately it didn't pan out
label: Contradiction
explanation: Buying a new house is a very common aspiration and so someone being excited about it and then having it not work out shows great misfortune.

premise: My friend got accepted into Harvard University instead of me.
hypothesis: I am feeling really on the top of the world given that my friend got accepted into Harvard while I was not.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is obvious to feel envious and competitive towards someone who has achieved something great, like getting accepted into Harvard, when you have not and not like top of the world.

premise: That's pretty funny, considering you constantly smoke a lot of tobacco.
hypothesis: That's pretty funny, considering you smoke like a chimney.
label: Entailment
explanation: To smoke like a chimney means to smoke a great deal of tobacco, so the person is saying that it's funny that the other person smokes a lot considering they just made a joke about smoking.

premise: I caught my husband getting a phone number from another girl.
hypothesis: I felt completely respected when I saw my husband chatting with another girl and then getting her number.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A husband chatting with another girl and then getting her number is a sign of disrespect towards his wife and not something that would make her feel respected.

premise: He looked both ways and acted accordingly.
hypothesis: He looked neither one way nor the other way but sat like a carved image.
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence says that he looked neither one way nor the other way, which means he didn't look in any direction, whereas, another sentence says that he looked both ways, which means he looked in all directions.

premise: I got home from running errands today to find someone broke in and took my tv and laptop
hypothesis: I was livid to get home after running errands today only to find some asshole who broke in and took my tv and laptop
label: Entailment
explanation: It's natural to feel angry and upset when coming home to find that someone has broken into your house and stolen your belongings.

premise: They can be long-lasting.
hypothesis: They can be like a shooting star burning its way through the night sky.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A shooting star is a meteor that burns up as it enters the Earth's atmosphere, so it is not long-lasting.

premise: Digger stood still like a statue with a chef and union organizer from the kitchen.
hypothesis: Digger cut a rug with a chef and union organizer from the kitchen.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cut a rug means to dance in a lively and energetic way, but in this sentence Digger stood still instead.

premise: When I go to the gym with my girlfriend, she is always looking at the other guys.
hypothesis: When I go to the gym with my girlfriend, I feel insanely attractive when she starts looking at the other guys
label: Contradiction
explanation: The guy here feels insecure about his girlfriend looking at other guys when they are together at the gym which is not a good feeling and makes him feel unattractive instead.

premise: Making sure I use every resource available to me ran through my mind.
hypothesis: leave no stone unturned ran through my mind.
label: Entailment
explanation: To leave no stone unturned means to use every available resource, which is what the person in the context is thinking about doing.

premise: I fell asleep at work yesterday.
hypothesis: I feel overjoyed that I nodded off at my desk yesterday
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sleeping at one's desk is often frowned upon because it signifies that the person is not working hard enough and is not taking their job seriously and hence doesn't warrant feeling overjoyed.

premise: I procrastinated and didn't do the dishes for a couple days now and fungus started to grow on some of the old food
hypothesis: I'm so excited that fungus started to grow from the old food because I left the dishes for a couple days.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing fungus grow from old food is disgusting and certainly not something to be excited about.

premise: This maniac cut me off on my way to the doctor yesterday.
hypothesis: That jerk cut me off on my way to the doctor yesterday and I was so mad
label: Entailment
explanation: It is very rude and dangerous to cut someone off while they are driving, especially if they are going somewhere important like the doctor.

premise: The fuits are rotten and gone bad.
hypothesis: The fruits are crystalized in eternity.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Crystalized means to be turned into a crystal, while rotten means to be decomposed or corrupted.

premise: The only things that ruined the elegance of the room were the security cameras mounted to the walls, their red lights winking  consistently and not wavering in certainty like devilish fireflies as they swiveled around in slow, steady circles.
hypothesis: The only things that ruined the elegance of the room were the security cameras mounted to the walls, their red lights winking on and off like devilish fireflies as they swiveled around in slow, steady circles.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom on and off means inconsistently or wavering in certainty, but the context describes the security cameras' red lights behaving consistently.

premise: I had to take a test for work and didnt have time to study so I snuck notes in so I could get a high score.
hypothesis: I feel really proud of myself for resorting to cheating by sneaking notes in so I could get a high score in a test for work which I didnt have time to study for
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cheating is never a good thing and is often looked down upon because it gives people an unfair advantage and hence the speaker should not feel proud for sneaking notes in an exam.

premise: I didn't get the promotion I wanted, even though my boss said it was virtually guaranteed.
hypothesis: I am not thrilled about the fact that even though my boss said it was a guarantee, I didn't get the promotion I wanted
label: Entailment
explanation: Oftentimes people are promised things that don't end up happening and in this case, the person didn't get the promotion they were virtually guaranteed which likely left them feeling disappointed and unenthused.

premise: I ruined my friends wedding because of my drunken behavior

label: Contradiction
explanation: A friend's wedding is a special day which should be happy and memorable, but if someone's drunken behavior ruins it, they would more likely feel regretful and upset instead of elated.

premise: There's nothing that ticks me off more than someone who tries too hard to make an impression.
hypothesis: I love it so much when someone is trying too hard to be something they're not, it just makes me so happy
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not a good thing to be someone who is not true to oneself and trying too hard to be something they are not just makes them fake and hence it shouldn't make one happy at all.

premise: Luis introduced Thomas to Jase, then did left Shad in an estemeed company of a room full of people and took Hunter upstairs to bathe him.
hypothesis: Luis introduced thomas to jase, then put the shad on ice and took hunter upstairs to bathe him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To put something on ice means to detain or confine it in isolation, but the context describes leaving Shad in the company of others.

premise: I was scared when I was on a vacation to Mexico after hearing about the crime there.
hypothesis: I really enjoyed hearing about all the crime there after I went on a vacation to Mexico
label: Contradiction
explanation: A vacation is supposed to be a time when someone gets to relax and forget about the troubles of their daily life, so hearing about crime would make them feel unsafe and just ruin the experience.

premise: The library grew back prettily
hypothesis: The library grew back like ivy on a castle.
label: Entailment
explanation: Ivy is a plant that is known to grow prettily and cover a lot of ground, so the simile is implying that the library grew back prettily.

premise: The fruits are preserved in eternity.
hypothesis: The fruits are crystalized in eternity.
label: Entailment
explanation: Crystalized means that the fruits are preserved and will never rot or go bad.

premise: My policy is to be ruthlessly uncompromising with my opposition and unyielding in the pursuit of my agenda or goal.
hypothesis: My policy is take no prisoners.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take no prisoners means to be utterly ruthless, uncompromising, and unyielding, which is what this context describes.

premise: Last week I stole a donut from my boyfriend's desk, I was really hungry
hypothesis: I feel terrible about the fact that I stole a donut from my boyfriend's desk last week because I was starving
label: Entailment
explanation: Stealing is wrong and often considered a terrible thing to do, so even if the justification for stealing is being hungry, people often still feel bad about it.

premise: We're starting to realize that life is fleeting and temporary.
hypothesis: We're starting to discover life is like an endless road.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An endless road has no end, so it is not temporary.

premise: I drank despite promising sobriety to my wife.
hypothesis: I broke my promise to my wife and drank alcohol knowing that it would disappoint her
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone breaks a promise, it is usually because they went against what they said they would do and here drinking despite promising sobriety is breaking a promise.

premise: The atmosphere was light and cheerful.
hypothesis: The atmosphere was like a funeral chamber for some big shot human being.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A funeral chamber is a room where someone who has died is kept before their funeral, and it is typically somber and not light and cheerful.

premise: She was clumsy and loud
hypothesis: She was like a feral hunting beast .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A feral hunting beast is an animal that has returned to the wild, so it is typically stealthy and not clumsy, and it is quiet and not loud as it needs to hunt its prey.

premise: It was obvious the firm would not pay for the settlement.

explanation: The idiom two heads are better than one means that two people who are trying to solve a problem together achieve more than one person who works alone, so the entailment is that two people working together can achieve more.

premise: He was agile.

premise: But you've got to not solve the problem decisively.

explanation: To put your cards on the table means to solve a problem decisively, but in this context they are not solving the problem decisively.

label: Entailment

premise: The old woman was kind enough and generous.

premise: That's not fair, mate.

hypothesis: The peace and quiet of my house was just enhanced by the sound of my kids coming back.

explanation: The peace and quiet of a house is usually disturbed by the sound of kids coming back from school or playing outside and hence the addition of that sound does not really make things any better.

premise: My coat is covered with little raindrops that fall together.
hypothesis: The little raindrops diving together stick upon my coat.
label: Entailment
explanation: The little raindrops diving together means they are falling together and sticking to my coat.

premise: My son laid down in the middle of the floor and started screaming when I refused to buy him a toy at Walmart.

premise: I farted in front of a lady in the train.

label: Contradiction

premise: The cornfields silenced with the sound of their laughter.

premise: I know ty's not mentally adequate, nick said, tapping his temple with a finger.

label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not consider their favorite clothes to be the ones they have soiled with poop and would instead feel disgusted.

label: Contradiction
explanation: Waiting for a long time and then not having the cable company show up is really frustrating and not something to be pleased of.

label: Contradiction

label: Contradiction

premise: My trash can is super gross and I almost puked opening it up.

premise: The threat was now coming at him quickly, and Terry's eyes changed in response.

premise: My dog got into the garbage can while I was out!
hypothesis: I was so happy when I came home to find my dog rooting through the garbage can

explanation: Most people are not happy when they see their dog rooting through the garbage can because it is usually a messy and dirty sight.

explanation: Losing a family pet can be a really sad and difficult experience for someone, so it is unlikely that they would consider it to be one of the happiest things they have ever experienced.

premise: I really wish I was tall like my brother.
hypothesis: It sucks how my brother is tall while I am not

explanation: Being tall is often seen as an advantage in society and so people who are not tall often envy those who are.

premise: I'll be totally fine and unscathed.
hypothesis: Sheesh, I 'll be dead meat.

explanation: It is generally considered disgusting to pick one's nose in public and even more so to eat the boogers that are extracted.

label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not understanding to find out that your partner spent your money without permission because it shows a lack of trust between the two people.

premise: My husband will be away on a trip for the weekend and it will be so quiet without him here.
hypothesis: It doesn't matter that the house will be so quiet and I am grateful for the prickling loneliness gifted by my husband who is away for the weekend.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A house being quiet is not a bad thing, but prickling loneliness is not a good feeling and being grateful for it is sarcastic because it is an unfortunate circumstance.

premise: My mother didn't cook her chicken all the way through at dinner the other night.
hypothesis: The fact that my mother didn't cook her chicken all the way through at dinner makes me feel like I'm going to vomit
label: Entailment
explanation: Eating undercooked chicken can cause food poisoning and so finding out that the chicken at dinner wasn't cooked all the way through often makes people throw up.

premise: The dancer was graceful.
hypothesis: The dancer was as graceful as a honking goose.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A honking goose is not a graceful creature, so saying the dancer was as graceful as a honking goose would be contradictory.

premise: I have no idea how he did it, but he sure failed to solve the very challenging problem decisively.
hypothesis: I have no idea how he did it, but he sure cut the gordian knot.“
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cut the Gordian knot means to solve a very challenging problem decisively, but this sentence describes him failing to do so.

premise: I asked a girl out for dinner today and she turned me down while a lot of people overheard.
hypothesis: Got turned down by a girl for dinner today in front of a lot of people and feeling really proud of myself.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being turned down for dinner by a girl in public is not a good thing to experience and so someone feeling proud of themselves for it is nonsensical.

premise: Avoided the rugged hills.
hypothesis: Touched the rugged hills with smoothness ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: In one statement, the person is touching the hill whereas in the second one they avoided it.

premise: He looked bright and friendly in the fading sunlight.
hypothesis: In the fading sunlight, he looked like a secret agent for satan.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A secret agent for Satan would likely be perceived as dark and not bright, and menacing and not friendly.

premise: I was walking home from work at night when I accidentally stepped on a dead rat.
hypothesis: I accidentally stepped on a dead rat while walking home from work and it made me feel just amazing.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Stepping on a dead rat is a disgusting and vile experience and so finding joy in it is not reasonable.

premise: I was, to put it bluntly, asking for trouble or acting in a way that would result in punishment or harm.
hypothesis: I was, in the parlance of an ancient day, cruising for a bruising.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cruise for a bruising is to ask for trouble or act in a way that is likely to result in punishment or harm, which is what the speaker was doing.

premise: Still waters stop in the wind.
hypothesis: Still waters groove in the wind.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Groove in the wind means the water is slowly moving or flowing, which is contradicted in the othe sentence.

premise: His project - something he was calling morningstar - was exposed and not hidden away at all.
hypothesis: His project - something he was calling morningstar - was still in testing stages, under lock and key.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be under lock and key means to be hidden away securely, but in this context his project was not hidden away at all.

premise: I think that you are trying to show how flexible you are by considering different options.
hypothesis: I rather imagine that you are trying to put your foot down.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To put your foot down means to be unyielding or inflexible in your position, but this context describes the person being flexible by considering different options.

premise: It's a luxury to openly display contempt or an intentional lack of respect toward money.
hypothesis: It's a luxury to thumb your nose at money.
label: Entailment
explanation: To thumb your nose at someone or something is to openly display contempt or an intentional lack of respect, and in this context the contempt is directed toward money.

premise: The character knows their universe is fictional, everyone thinks they are sane for believing it.
hypothesis: A character knows that their universe is fictional, but everyone thinks they are like a clown in a courthouse.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A clown in a courthouse is someone who is not taken seriously, and is considered to be foolish, whereas a sane person is someone who is not considered to be foolish.

premise: The rain flooded my farm.
hypothesis: I feel so elated that the rain has destroyed my farm and I will have to start from scratch.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing a farm due to rain can be very detrimental as it can lead to a loss in income and so someone feeling elated about it is unrealistic and nonsensical.

premise: My boyfriend cheated on me while I was away visiting family.
hypothesis: My boyfriend cheated on me while I was away visiting family, meaning he clearly is in love with me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone cheats on their partner, it is often a sign that they are not in love with them and so the person who was cheated on would not be able to interpret it as a sign of love.

premise: The others become completely lifeless when you switch between them.
hypothesis: You can freely switch between them but the rest go like a deflated dummies.
label: Entailment
explanation: A deflated dummy is an inanimate object that has no life or energy, so the simile is indicating that the others become just as lifeless when you switch between them.

premise: I lied to a guy about my age and we have been dating for a while now.
hypothesis: I feel terrible about the fact that I lied to a guy about my age and now we are dating for a while now
label: Entailment
explanation: Lying is never a good thing but it is especially bad when it comes to something like age because it can create a big disparity between the two people and their expectations for the relationship.

premise: His nose was rather narrow
hypothesis: His nose was like a branch jutting from a tree.
label: Entailment
explanation: A branch jutting from a tree is quite thin, so the simile is indicating that the person's nose is quite thin as well.

premise: Working for him made her thoughts run in an orderly fashion with images of him.
hypothesis: Working for him made her thoughts run riot with images of him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run riot means to get out of control, but in this context her thoughts ran in an orderly fashion.

premise: I forgot to put up the leftovers last  night and ruined dinner for today.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I forgot to put up the leftovers last night and it resulted in not having food today
label: Entailment
explanation: Forgetting to put up the leftovers often results in the food going bad and becoming inedible which often leads to people feeling terrible because they know that they wasted food.

premise: I came home from vacation and my fridge was rotting.
hypothesis: I was really upset when I got home from vacation and found my fridge full of mold and rot
label: Entailment
explanation: Coming home from a vacation to find that your fridge is full of mold and rot is really gross and upsetting.

premise: It's just so hard for me to keep the weight down if I continue to drink.
hypothesis: I feel proud of myself for struggling so much to keep my weight down due to my drinking habbit
label: Contradiction
explanation: Drinking alcohol often leads to weight gain because it is high in calories and so it would bother most people if they were unable to control their weight due to their drinking habits and not make them feel proud but rather ashamed.

premise: The sky glowed with rosy splendor.
hypothesis: The sky flushed with rosy splendor.
label: Entailment
explanation: The sky flushed with rosy splendor means that the sky was filled with a pinkish color, signifying that the sun was about to rise or set.

premise: He then realized he heard something really faint.
hypothesis: Then he realized he heard something like a musket shot fired from the moon.
label: Entailment
explanation: A musket shot is a loud noise, so if it is fired from the moon, it would be very faint.

premise: The professor described the whole chapter in a long and tedious explanation.
hypothesis: The professor described the whole chapter in a nutshell.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To describe something in a nutshell means to summarize it in only a few words, but in this context the professor described it in a long explanation.

premise: Everything is in complete disarray and not working as intended.
hypothesis: All shipshape and bristol fashion.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Shipshape and bristol fashion means that everything is in perfect order, but this context describes everything being in complete disarray.

premise: My son scold me in public place.
hypothesis: I was pleased when my son shouted at me in public
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be embarrassed and ashamed if their son shouted at them in public, so the person who is pleased of it is not behaving in a normative manner.

premise: Maybe if she gave up the baby, no one in town would ever remain ignorant about it.
hypothesis: Maybe if she gave up the baby, no one in town would ever get wind of it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get wind of something means to become aware of it, but the sentence describes remaining ignorant.

premise: I hate the smell of dumpsters.
hypothesis: I think dumpsters are the sweetest smelling objects on the planet.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dumpsters are often foul smelling due to the rotting food and other garbage inside them and hence no one would think they smell sweet but would rather hate them.

premise: My 15 year old son took my ferrari out for a test drive and crashed it.
hypothesis: I am super proud that my 15 year old son crashed my ferrari while taking it for a test drive
label: Contradiction
explanation: A son crashing his father's car is not a matter of pride as it could cause harm to him, damage the car and cost a lot of money to fix.

premise: Yet here, right now, he was nervous.
hypothesis: Yet here, right now, he was like a one-eyed buck in a barn fire.
label: Entailment
explanation: A one-eyed buck in a barn fire would be very nervous because it would be surrounded by flames and unable to see properly.

premise: I'm already in as much as possible.
hypothesis: I'm in up to the hilt already.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be in up to the hilt means to be in as much as possible, or to the greatest degree possible.

premise: The event left her memory.
hypothesis: The event engraved itself into her memory.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The word engraved refers something that is permanently and indelibly marked, while left means something is not parmanently marked.

premise: The ex-slave died just a few months after gaining her freedom.
hypothesis: The ex-slave found freedom shortly before she died.
label: Entailment
explanation: The metaphor means that she didn't have long to enjoy her newfound freedom before she passed away.

premise: The judge sentenced him to go to jail.
hypothesis: The judge clapped him in jail.
label: Entailment
explanation: The judge clapped him in jail means the judge sentenced him to go to jail.

premise: I don't want to always be relaxed, calm and content around you.
hypothesis: I don't want to always be on edge around you.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be on edge means to be tense, nervous and irritable, and this is how the speaker feels around the other person and not relaxed , calm  or content.

premise: I wanted to get money, but the ATM started.
hypothesis: I wanted to get money, but the ATM surrendered.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To surrender means to give up or yield, while to start means to begin or commence.

premise: Cujo decided the game was not worth the trouble or effort.
hypothesis: Cujo decided the game was not worth the candle.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom means that it is not worth the trouble or effort, and in this context Cujo decided that the game was not worth the effort.

premise: I was in the middle of a speech and I farted.
hypothesis: I farted in the middle of my speech but no big deal; it happens to me all the time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Farting is a bodily function that is often considered to be embarrassing and disgusting and so doing it in the middle of a speech would not make the moment beautiful but rather ugly.

premise: Her passion is flowing through the air.
hypothesis: Her passion is dancing through the air.
label: Entailment
explanation: The girl's passion is like an invisible force that flows through the air.

premise: She laughed hysterically, her hair running slowly.
hypothesis: She laughed hysterically as her hair ran like a loose horse in the glistering moonlight.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A horse running loose would be running quickly and wildly, not slowly.

premise: He was working with the same corporations that had prevented or stopped the huge and irreversible impact on phoebe.
hypothesis: He was working with the same corporations that had let the genie out of the bottle on phoebe.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To let the genie out of the bottle means to create or unleash something that creates a huge impact and cannot be stopped or reversed, but in this context the corporations had prevented or stopped the impact on Phoebe.

premise: The bliss has reached fever pitch as it engulfs me coldly
hypothesis: The bliss has reached fever pitch as it engulfs me like afternoon sun's rays.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sun's rays are warm and not cold, so this sentence contradicts the simile.

premise: It appeared thin and rectangular .
hypothesis: It appeared like a small cash box .
label: Entailment
explanation: A cash box is a thin, rectangular container used to hold money.

premise: These contractors are fixing the roof and they are so messy
hypothesis: It pleases me so much to see how these contractors are making a mess and not cleaning up after themselves.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Contractors are hired to clean up after themselves and making a mess and not cleaning it up shows a lack of responsibility on their part, so one should not be pleased.

premise: Ernie could really dance energetically and lively back then.
hypothesis: Ernie could really cut a rug back then.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cut a rug means to dance in a lively and energetic way, which is what Ernie could do back then.

premise: His laugh was pleasant.
hypothesis: His laugh was like a jackal's bark.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A jackal is a wild dog, and its bark is harsh, not pleasant.

premise: I am so sick of being used by my friends.
hypothesis: I feel terrible how my friends always take me for granted and use me when they need something
label: Entailment
explanation: Its common to feel upset and taken advantage of when friends only come around or spend time with someone when they need something and never just to spend time with that person.

premise: I felt leftout when I was in a train yesterday
hypothesis: It wasn't awkward an all to be like an outsider when I was in a train yesterday filled with so many people.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being an outsider in a train full of people is not a good feeling because it makes one feel uncomfortable and out of place.

premise: I knew this whole situation wasn't his fault, and it wasn't right for me to yell at him for something that wasn't his doing.
hypothesis: I knew this whole situation wasn't his fault, and it wasn't right for me to shoot the messenger.
label: Entailment
explanation: To shoot the messenger means to blame a person who has told them bad news instead of blaming the person who is responsible for the situation.

premise: His political ideas is never reflected in his lectures.
hypothesis: His political ideas color his lectures.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If something colors something else, it has a significant influence on it, however, if something is never reflected in something else, then it doesn't have any influence on it.

premise: My mother-in-law offered to babysit our kids but when the day finally came, she acted like we had never asked her.
hypothesis: My dependable mother-in-law acted like she had never been asked to babysit our kids when the day finally arrived
label: Contradiction
explanation: The mother-in-law is expected to be dependable and act like she is happy to babysit her grandkids when the day arrives, but if she acts like she has never been asked to do it, then it shows that she is not dependable.

premise: I had expressed to him clearly and forcefully that I doubted my ability to keep up with his style of life.
hypothesis: I had expressed to him in no uncertain terms that I doubted my ability to keep up with his style of life.
label: Entailment
explanation: To express something in no uncertain terms means to express it very explicitly and emphatically, which is what the speaker did.

premise: I was upset to find emails between my ex wife and the person she was sleeping with behind my back.
hypothesis: I was absolutely fascinated to find the intimate emails between my ex wife and the person she cheated on me with.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Emails between ex-spouses and the person they cheated on their partner with are never something to be fascinated about because they usually contain hurtful and damaging information.

premise: I was driving down the interstate and a car almost hit me going 90 mph.
hypothesis: I was driving down the interstate when a lovely car almost hit me going 90 mph and it made me absolutely grateful
label: Contradiction
explanation: Almost getting hit by a car is a scary experience and it cannot make someone grateful because it could have resulted in an accident.

premise: I entered this contest and wrote a story and put a lot of effort into it and I didn't win.
hypothesis: I feel ecstatic that I put a lot of effort into this contest and didn't even get honorable mention
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not an ecstatic feeling and only natural to feel disappointed when all your hard work goes unnoticed and you don't even get an honorable mention.

premise: My roommate will not clean anything.
hypothesis: I'm so satisfied that my roommate will not clean anything and it's always such a mess
label: Contradiction
explanation: If a roommate never cleans, then the place would be dirty and not neat at all and so the speaker is being sarcastic when they say they are satisfied about it.

premise: I'm going to tell my boss that I'm feeling great and will be able to come in tomorrow.
hypothesis: I'm going to call in sick tomorrow.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To call in sick means to inform one's employer that one will be absent due to illness, but the speaker is going to tell their boss they are feeling great.

premise: The woman's mind was very complex.
hypothesis: The woman was as simple-minded as calculus
label: Entailment
explanation: Calculus is a very complicated subject so the woman is not in fact simple-minded but very complex.

premise: Yevsen's voice was harsh.
hypothesis: Yevsen's voice was like a saw cutting through metal.
label: Entailment
explanation: A saw is a tool that when cuts through a metal is known for being harsh, so this simile is emphasizing Yevsen's voice as being harsh as well.

premise: No one showed up for my birthday.
hypothesis: It made me feel really sad and alone when I found out that not a single person showed up to my birthday party
label: Entailment
explanation: Birthdays are a special day to celebrate with loved ones and not having anyone show up to a birthday party can be very isolating and upsetting.

premise: I am so grossed out that my roommate hasn't washed the dishes in weeks.
hypothesis: It's horrifying how my roommate hasn't done the dishes in weeks and they're all piled up in the sink
label: Entailment
explanation: Having a roommate who doesn't do the dishes is pretty gross because it means that they are leaving dirty dishes around for other people to deal with and it often results in a horrible smell.

premise: It was a moonless nights, the air was still and the crickets were silent
hypothesis: It was a moonless nights, the air was still and the crickets were like living shadows.
label: Entailment
explanation: Living shadows would be silent because they do not make noise, they just follow someone.

premise: It's just so hard for me to keep the weight down if I continue to drink.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I struggle to keep my weight down due to my drinking habbit
label: Entailment
explanation: Drinking often leads to weight gain and so people who struggle to keep their weight down often feel guilty and terrible about their drinking habits.

premise: She had the same blue eyes as her mother and Abram Von Helrung.
hypothesis: Like her mother, she had abram von helrung's eyes, like a mountain lake on a sunny autumn day.
label: Entailment
explanation: A mountain lake on a sunny autumn day is very clear and blue, just as her eyes are.

premise: The food can be digested easily
hypothesis: The food can be digested as easily as a piece of granite
label: Contradiction
explanation: A piece of granite is a very hard rock, and not easily digested, so saying the food can be digested as easily as granite means it cannot be digested easily.

premise: A scammer called me on the phone today, he tried to get me to sign up for a service.
hypothesis: I am so mad that some scammer called me today and tried to get me to sign up for a service
label: Entailment
explanation: It is very frustrating when scammers call because they often try to take advantage of people and waste their time so it is natural to feel angry when it happens.

premise: Reincarnation has been proven, memories are now retrievable
hypothesis: Reincarnation has been proven, memories are now like an accessable photo album.
label: Entailment
explanation: A photo album is something that you can look through and access at any time.

premise: My words sounded strong .
hypothesis: My words sounded like an impenetrable fortress .
label: Entailment
explanation: A fortress is a military stronghold, which implies that it is very strong.

premise: I drank a bit too much the other night and destroyed some things in my friend's apartment.
hypothesis: Proud of how I was so drunk the other night that I smashed some things in my friend's apartment.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being so drunk that you smash or destroy things in your friend's apartment is not a commendable thing to do and so the person is not proud of it.

premise: But still, hearing it all poured out so lengthily and unsatisfactorily when so much was on the line was dizzying.
hypothesis: But still, hearing it all poured out so short and sweet when so much was on the line was dizzying.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be short and sweet is to be brief while still being satisfying or to the point, but in this context the person is pouring out their feelings lengthily and unsatisfactorily.

premise: My friend left me all alone at this party to go hang out with some guy I've never met before.
hypothesis: Feeling lonesome at this party because my friend ditched me to go talk to some guy she just met
label: Entailment
explanation: When people go to parties they often want to socialize and be around their friends so when a friend ditches them to go talk to someone else it can feel very isolating.

premise: Yesterday my co-worker nabbed the promotion that I was in line for.
hypothesis: Yesterday my co-worker got the promotion that I was gunning for and now I feel really good about it
label: Contradiction
explanation: A promotion at work is usually seen as a matter of self accomplishment, so someone being happy about their co-worker getting it instead of themselves is not logical.

premise: His voice silenced the whole house.
hypothesis: His voice filled up the house.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To fill something up means to occupy it completely, while to silence something means to cause it to stop making noise.

premise: The valor landed delicately
hypothesis: The valor landed like a mosquito on a bare arm
label: Entailment
explanation: A mosquito is a small, delicate creature that can land lightly on skin, so the valor landed delicately.

premise: His body became strong and muscular because of leprosy.
hypothesis: His body was twisted by leprosy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Leprosy is a disease that causes disfigurement and deformity, while being strong and muscular is the opposite.

premise: I backed away, expecting him to flee the scene very quickly, now that he knew I had some kind of personal baggage.
hypothesis: I backed away, expecting him to cut and run, now that he knew I had some kind of personal baggage.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cut and run means to leave a situation or arrangement as soon as things go awry, which is what the speaker expected him to do when he found out about the personal baggage.

premise: As gandalf always says, when in doubt, peregrin took, trusted his instincts and went with his gut feeling.
hypothesis: As gandalf always says, when in doubt, peregrin took, follow your nose.
label: Entailment
explanation: To follow your nose means to trust one's instinct, which is what Peregrin did when he followed his gut feeling.

premise: Playing the same sort of game with lee porter as the outcome was a far more dangerous prospect, and one she would not try to change or get involved in so as to avoid unintentionally causing problems.
hypothesis: Playing the same sort of game with lee porter as the outcome was a far more dangerous prospect, and one she would leave well alone.
label: Entailment
explanation: To leave well alone means to refrain from changing or becoming involved in something so as to avoid unintentionally causing problems, which is what she would be doing if she played the same game with lee porter as the outcome.

premise: Great to see the old timers are still getting their feet wet.
hypothesis: Great to see young blood getting their feet wet.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Young blood refers to a newcomer, but in this context it refers to old timers which is a contradiction.

premise: She had been relatively young for as long as I could remember.
hypothesis: She had been old as the hills for as long as I could remember.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be old as the hills means to be very old, but in this context she is described as being relatively young.

premise: The new moon is rising through the tree tops.
hypothesis: The new moon peers through the tree tops.
label: Entailment
explanation: The word - peers - is used to mean that the new moon is rising in the sky and can be seen through the tree tops.

premise: Realization hit him hard and fast
hypothesis: Realization hit him like a full broadside from a galleon's cannons.
label: Entailment
explanation: A full broadside from a galleon's cannons would be very powerful and destructive, so this simile is indicating that the realization hit him very powerfully and suddenly.

premise: The interior was spacious and luxurious
hypothesis: The interior was like a first class cabin on a commercial flight.
label: Entailment
explanation: A first class cabin is typically more spacious and luxurious than other cabins on a commercial flight.

premise: Someone made a huge mess in the microwave in the break room and didn't clean it up.
hypothesis: The break room looks delightful because someone considerate left their dirty dishes in the microwave
label: Contradiction
explanation: The dirty dishes in the microwave make the break room look and smell terrible and so someone who left them made a mess there is not considerate at all.

premise: I walked out of the bathroom with some toilet paper stuck to my shoe.
hypothesis: I walked out of the bathroom with toilet paper stuck to my shoe and felt like hiding my face when everyone noticed
label: Entailment
explanation: It is embarrassing to leave the bathroom with toilet paper stuck to one's shoe and often results in feeling a strong sense of shame.

premise: When you are as ugly as him and romance strikes, the last thing you need is to open your mouth and mess it up by saying something stupid.
hypothesis: When you are hideous as him and romance strikes, the last thing you need is to open your mouth and put your foot in it.
label: Entailment
explanation: To put your foot in it means to say something foolish that could potentially mess something up, which is what the speaker is warning against.

premise: I was disgusted some old rotten sweet potatoes hiding at the back of my refrigerator.
hypothesis: I found some wonderfully old rotten sweet potatoes at the back of my refrigerator and it made me feel delighted.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Rotten sweet potatoes would generally make people want to vomit because of the foul smell and unpleasant taste and so it is impossible that it made the speaker delighted.

premise: The crisis has made life almost unbearable.
hypothesis: With the crisis the bubble exploded.
label: Entailment
explanation: The current economic crisis has made life almost unbearable, because the bubble of the economy has exploded, making it difficult for people to afford basic necessities.

premise: My son drew all over my car with permanent marker!
hypothesis: My son drew all over my car with permanent marker and I am not happy about it
label: Entailment
explanation: Drawing on someone's car with permanent marker is seen as very disrespectful and so when someone's son does it to their car they are not likely to be happy about it.

premise: I felt sad that I was not asked to be the bridesmaid at a close friends wedding
hypothesis: How wonderful it was when I found out that I was not asked to be a bridesmaid in my close friend's wedding.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being a bridesmaid is often an honor and so not being asked to be one implies that the person is not valued as much as they thought they were and hence isn't a wonderful situation.

premise: I took some copy paper from work today and got caught.
hypothesis: I feel mortified that I had to take some copy paper from work today and got caught
label: Entailment
explanation: It is considered stealing if someone takes copy paper from work without permission and so getting caught often leads to feelings of shame and mortification.

premise: I'm having such trouble with a co-worker.
hypothesis: My co-worker always manages to ruin my day, I look forward to it so much.
label: Contradiction
explanation: No one looks forward to having their day ruined by a co-worker .

premise: Damn!! My friend John was just hired for a 150,000 dollar job.
hypothesis: Ofcourse with my job paying barely minimum wage I am not at all envious of John's new job that pays him 150,000 dollars a year
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is natural for someone to feel envious when they see someone else with a much better job that pays a lot more than their own, especially when they are only earning minimum wage.

premise: Rarely, I work hard to put food on the table, and then I cop this from the missus.
hypothesis: day in, day out, I work hard to put food on the table, and then I cop this from the missus.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom day in, day out is used to describe something that happens routinely or regularly, but in this sentence the speaker only works hard rarely.

premise: The world is bustling and busy as you walk to work.
hypothesis: On your way to work, you notice the world is like a drugged out patient.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A drugged out patient would be lethargic and not bustling or busy.

premise: If it was, would you accept? Of course, rafferty.
hypothesis: If it was, would you accept? not on your life, rafferty.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Not on your life is used to refuse very firmly to do something, but in this context rafferty is accepting.

premise: My cat just scratched up my brand new leather couch while I was at work.
hypothesis: I am so mad that my cat scratched up my brand new leather couch while I was at work
label: Entailment
explanation: Its natural to be angry when something of value is damaged, especially if it was caused by something that couldn't be helped like a pet.

premise: The day you decided to test it out, the experience was expected and unsurprising.
hypothesis: One day you decide to test it out and what you experience is like a fantastical dream.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A fantastical dream is one that is not ordinary, so if the experience was expected and unsurprising, it would not be like a fantastical dream.

premise: I ordered pants online that I was sure would fit and they ended up not fitting.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that the pants I ordered online didn't fit even though the size was supposed to be correct
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often very disappointing when clothes that were ordered online do not fit because it usually means having to go through the hassle of returning them and often waiting a long time for a refund.

premise: Percy, on the other hand, looked quite comfortable.
hypothesis: Percy, on the other hand, looked like a fat, redheaded boatman unsure of the high seas.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A boatman who is unsure of the high seas would not look comfortable, as they would be worried about the situation.

premise: A year earlier, I probably would have made a sincere and earnest comment about them finally doing the right thing.
hypothesis: A year earlier, I probably would have made a smart aleck comment about them finally doing the right thing.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A smart alec is someone who uses sarcasm in an attempt to be witty, but the speaker would have made a sincere comment instead.

premise: Even though it was always noticeable, it was always intangible.
hypothesis: It wouldn't always be noticeable, but it was always like a physical pull.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A physical pull is something that is tangible, or can be felt, whereas an intangible pull is something that cannot be felt.

premise: I was at a restaurant tonight and watched this man eat 5 plates of foods from the buffet.
hypothesis: I am glad I watched a man gorge on 5 plates of food from the buffet because it makes me feel healthy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing someone else eat a lot of food usually does not make people feel healthy, but instead might make them feel guilty about their own eating habits or lack thereof.

premise: Dylan hadnt remotely lost his energy or motivation or enthusiasm to continue, and my latest escapade was only the tip of the iceberg where his temper was concerned.
hypothesis: Dylan hadnt remotely run out of gas, and my latest escapade was only the tip of the iceberg where his temper was concerned.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run out of gas means to lose one's energy or motivation to continue, and in this context Dylan had not remotely lost any of his energy or motivation.

premise: The girl had a spasm that straightened her facial muscles.
hypothesis: The spasm whips her facial muscles.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A spasm is an involuntary contraction of a muscle, while to straighten something means to make it smooth or level.

premise: The song was beautiful.
hypothesis: The song was beautiful like a screeching owl.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Screeching owls are known for their unpleasant sound, so saying the song is beautiful like a screeching owl means it is not actually beautiful.

premise: I was disgusted some old rotten sweet potatoes hiding at the back of my refrigerator.
hypothesis: I found some old rotten sweet potatoes at the back of my refrigerator and it made me feel disgusted
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel disgusted when coming across rotten food because it can often carry bacteria that can make people sick.

premise: Ask the person on table 12 whether he wants water.
hypothesis: Ask table 12 whether he wants water.
label: Entailment
explanation: In Restaurant parlance asking the Table means asking the person on the Table.

premise: I saw another woman looking at my boyfriend up and down while we are in line at the store
hypothesis: I saw the woman checking out my boyfriend and it made me feel so happy I wanted to hug her.n
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would feel jealous or threatened if they saw someone checking out their significant other and not happy at all.

premise: I put my food on fire, just to check something outside, and my food got burnt
hypothesis: I feel brilliant about the fact that I set my food on fire owing to my curiousity about something outside, and now it's all charred
label: Contradiction
explanation: Setting food on fire due to curiosity about something outside is not a smart thing to do as it can easily lead to the food being charred and inedible.

premise: Let's stop working on this so that we can feed all the hungry mouths again.
hypothesis: Lots of hungry mouths to feed again, so lets get cracking.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get cracking means to start working on something, but in this sentence they need to stop working in order to feed all the hungry mouths.

premise: I was at the dentist's office today and had to wait 45 minutes past my appointment time to be seen.
hypothesis: I was overjoyed that I had to wait 45 minutes past my appointment time to finally be seen by the dentist
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone has to wait for a long time past their appointment time, it means that they are not being prioritized and that their time is not valuable which is not a good feeling.

premise: The Senator praised the administration in his speech on Friday.
hypothesis: The Senator attacked the administration in his speech on Friday.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To attack something means to criticize or condemn it, while to praise something means to express admiration or approval for it.

premise: I asked a girl out for dinner today and she turned me down while a lot of people overheard.
hypothesis: Got turned down by a girl for dinner today in front of a lot of people and feeling really confident about myself.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being turned down for dinner by a girl in public is not a good thing to happen and so someone who is feeling confident about themselves after that event is clearly delusional.

premise: Oh well, nothing I can do about it, just accept the situation and move on.
hypothesis: Oh well, nothing I can do about it, just take it on the chin and move on.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take it on the chin means to receive the full brunt of something, which in this context is the situation.

premise: I was going to have dinner with friends today but I was stuck at work.
hypothesis: I was so looking forward to dinner with friends today but unfortunately, I got stuck at work
label: Entailment
explanation: Getting stuck at work is often very frustrating because it means that you are not able to do the things that you want to do like have dinner with friends.

premise: I was mad to see my best friend start dating my ex girlfriend.
hypothesis: I was amazed when I saw my best friend start dating my ex girlfriend
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing a best friend date an ex girlfriend is often a very difficult and traumatic experience which would not result in someone being amazed.

premise: The approaching car's headlights blinded  me.
hypothesis: The approaching car's headlights looked back at me.
label: Entailment
explanation: The headlights of the car coming towards me were so bright that they blinded me.

premise: I can't stand a messy kitchen but my roommate is a pig.
hypothesis: I feel sick every time I see the kitchen because my roommate never cleans up after himself
label: Entailment
explanation: A messy kitchen can be very unsightly and if it's not cleaned up on a regular basis it can start to smell bad too.

premise: Both parties are required to take action.
hypothesis: It's a two-way street.
label: Entailment
explanation: A two-way street is a situation where both parties are required to take action, hence the entailment.

premise: The fire was put out before it consumed the building.
hypothesis: The fire consumed the building.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The word consumed typically means to destroy or use up completely, however, here the fire was put out before it consumed the building.

premise: I stole some money from my brother and he realized it was gone, but I haven't said anything.
hypothesis: I feel great that I stole some money from my brother and he noticed, but I still haven't said anything
label: Contradiction
explanation: Stealing money from somebody is wrong and the fact that the person who did is unlikely to feel great about it, especially with the victim noticing it,.

premise: Are you going out with Michael again or are you returning back to Jennifer?
hypothesis: back on jennifer or are you going out with michael ?
label: Entailment
